title: Wheels of Justice Lurch After Los Angeles Riots
description: Thousands of people were arrested during the riots last spring on charges of arson, assault, looting and curfew violations, clogging the courts and jails beyond capacity. But five months later only a handful of people have been imprisoned, and officials say most of the serious offenders are likely to go unpunished.

title: Coleman Aims High, Expecting Nets to Leap
description: Two goals Derrick Coleman has in mind for 1992-93: He makes the Eastern Conference All-Star team, and the New Jersey Nets make the National Basketball Association finals.

title: Perot Shows He's the Master of Live TV
description: If there was a clear lesson to the Presidential debate on Sunday night, it was this: Be careful whom you invite.

title: 2 Die and 13 Are Injured in Car Accident
description: Two men were killed and 13 other people were injured last night when a car struck a sports-utility truck at a Bronx intersection, causing the truck to flip over and collide with a van taking a group of people to a church meeting, the police said.

title: INSIDE
description: Nobel for a Cell Discovery

title: CUBAN EXILES TRY TO STOP PBS SHOW
description: The leaders of the most powerful Cuban exile political group here are threatening to sue to try to stop the showing of a new television documentary, saying its portrayal of the group's role in shaping American policy toward Cuba is defamatory.

title: Intel Reports Record Profit In 3d Quarter
description: The Intel Corporation reported record earnings and revenues today, but the company's shares slipped in heavy trading, possibly because a court ruling late Friday appeared to clear the way for the company's chief rival, Advanced Micro Devices, to compete with Intel on the advanced 486 chip for personal computers.

title: COLLEGE SOCCER REPORT
description: New Mexico

title: Rogers Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Dow Corning reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Stewart Sends Blue Jays a Message: Not So Fast
description: The Oakland Athletics were facing elimination from the post-season today, facing the conclusion of a hectic six-month ride that saw them overcome odds and injuries to position themselves for one more chance at a World Series. They did not want the ride to end today. Neither did Dave Stewart.

title: Both Czechs and Slovaks Must Rebuild; Hungarian Minority
description: To the Editor:

title: Americans Win Nobel for Clues to Cell Signals
description: TWO American scientists, Dr. Edmond H. Fischer and Dr. Edwin G. Krebs, won the 1992 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine yesterday for an accidental discovery about cell proteins made in the 1950's.

title: Morris and Nets Closing In
description: The New Jersey Nets reached an agreement in principle today with Chris Morris, the team's restricted free-agent small forward and remaining holdout.

title: Pirates Not Awed a Bit By the Braves' Front Line
description: Exhibiting a large dose of resiliency, the Pittsburgh Pirates went to Atlanta today buoyed by their success in piercing the Braves' supposedly impenetrable front line of defense and cautiously optimistic of reversing the outcome of 1991.

title: Robert Trumbull Dies at 80; Reported on War for Times
description: Robert Trumbull, who chronicled war, the birth of nations and sweeping economic change in Asia and the Pacific region in more than three decades as a correspondent for The New York Times, died on Sunday at a hospital in Honolulu. He was 80 years old.

title: Abrams Calls Sen. D'Amato 'A Fascist'
description: Robert Abrams called Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato "a fascist" at a political rally late Sunday, then refused to apologize today, although he acknowledged that the remark was "unfortunate" and said it was triggered by his anger and frustration over Mr. D'Amato's campaign tactics.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Ratings; TV Ratings for First Debate Top Baseball Playoff Game
description: The Presidential debate on Sunday was a much bigger attraction than the American League baseball playoff, according to the overnight ratings for the 25 largest cities issued yesterday by the A.C. Nielsen Company.

title: Gaining From Turmoil in Currencies
description: The recent turmoil in the world's currency markets produced its share of casualties: central bankers who spent billions in a futile effort to prop up Europe's weaker currencies, government leaders who have seen the drive to European unification stalled and small American investors in global money-market funds who got burned when currencies like the pound fell sharply.

title: U.N. OFFICIAL ASKS SERBS TO END SIEGE
description: The United Nations military commander for this war-ravaged country opened talks here today with Serbian nationalist leaders on a plan to lift the siege of Sarajevo before winter by opening what he called "a gate" to the city through a strategic suburb now controlled by Serbian forces.

title: Corrections
description: A chronology on Saturday about the Iraq bank fraud case referred incorrectly to a letter that the Central Intelligence Agency provided the Justice Department on Sept. 17. The letter was unclassified.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail; A Libertarian Fails to Make The Big Time
description: Ever hear of Andre Marrou? Probably not. But he's out there on the Presidential campaign trail too, somewhere, running hard, just like George Bush and Bill Clinton and Ross Perot.

title: Daniel Horn, Who Linked Cancer With Cigarette Use, Is Dead at 76
description: Dr. Daniel Horn, whose research on the negative effects of cigarette smoking helped to influence government policy and public attitudes, died on Wednesday at the Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived in Frenchtown, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of murder-mystery events in Weekend on Friday misstated the information telephone number for mystery dinners that start on Nov. 21 at the Yankee Clipper restaurant, John and South Streets, in lower Manhattan. It is (212) 362-7569.

title: Voyage on Fifth Avenue Brings Out Politicians
description: Embracing tradition over revisionism, several of the state's leading political figures, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor David N. Dinkins, Geraldine A. Ferraro and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, joined yesterday in celebrating a fabled Italian who is now under siege as more exploiter than explorer.

title: Main Topics for Marketers: Economy and the Election
description: THE dual concerns of the sputtering economy and the looming election dominated the discussions yesterday here at the 83d Annual Meeting and Business Conference of the Association of National Advertisers.

title: Vintage Redskins, And a Nod To Monk
description: The Washington Redskins entered tonight's game with the Denver Broncos as if their season, if not their pride, was squarely in jeopardy. Their 34-3 victory kept them from falling below .500 and set up their first of two divisional bouts with the Philadelphia Eagles here on Sunday.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: American Festival of Microtonal Music N.Y.U. Theater

title: Business and Health; Dealing in Myths On Malpractice
description: BOTH President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton want to change the system under which patients can bring medical malpractice lawsuits against doctors and hospitals. But the Congressional Budget Office and other experts who have studied the numbers say such proposals are based on sketchy and often misleading beliefs about the costs involved.

title: Market Place; Money Managers Considering the Clinton Effect
description: Fred Alger, who manages $2 billion for several mutual funds, pension providers and other accounts, plans to vote for George Bush. But last month, having become convinced that Bill Clinton would win, he sold his drug stocks to buy shares in health maintenance organizations that might profit from Mr. Clinton's efforts to control medical costs.

title: Winn-Dixie Stores Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 16
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $ 20,485,000.

title: VWR Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Alvin Rosenfeld, 73, Foreign Correspondent
description: Alvin Z. Rosenfeld, who was vice director for the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum and a foreign correspondent for newspapers and television, died on Saturday at Georgetown Hospital in Washington. He was 73 years old and lived in Washington.

title: U.S. and Europe Fail To Settle Trade Issues
description: Trade negotiators from the United States and the European Community were unable to reach an agreement today after two days of talks aimed at settling festering disputes that have blocked progress on a broader worldwide trade pact.

title: Books of The Times; Who Is Mark Leyner? A Legend in His Own Mind
description: Et Tu, Babe By Mark Leyner 168 pages. Harmony Books. $17.

title: Muzak's New Owners Seek Broader, High-Tech Market
description: Lily Tomlin once said: "I had a terrible dream last night. I dreamed that the man who invented Muzak invented something else."

title: Mississippi Law Fails to Reduce Abortion Strife
description: Two months after Mississippi became the first state to enforce a 24-hour waiting period for abortions, the two sides in the abortion debate agree on only one thing: a one-day waiting period is about a lot more than a single day.

title: Corrections
description: Articles yesterday and on Sunday about the Presidential debate misstated the location of the field house of Washington University, where it took place. The field house is in an unincorporated area of St. Louis County, not in Clayton, a suburb.

title: Q&A
description: Bats in the Belfry

title: Shevardnadze Wins in Georgia; Hard Tasks Loom
description: An overwhelming vote for Eduard A. Shevardnadze in national elections on Sunday has given the Georgian leader a strong hand with which to try to reimpose control in the rebellious province of Abkhazia.

title: Review/Music; The Mind Behind the Fingers of Glenn Gould
description: When Glenn Gould finished playing Bach's "Goldberg" Variations in Bruno Monsaingeon's 1981 film, shown at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday night as part of a nine-hour memorial tribute to this Canadian pianist, his hands lifted from the keys and shook in the air above the keyboard, stiffly, insistently, as if reluctant to let go, as if wanting to feel the tension remaining in the air. Throughout the performance, his hands jerked, conducted, marked time, but always quivered with tension, reacting almost tactilely to the music. During the slow variations his head was just inches above his hands, as if he were watching his fingers pull threads through the eyes of minuscule needles, weaving a tensile web of contrapuntal lines.

title: What Empty Feeling?
description: Dave Winfield searched for the right words, something that would put this crazy series into an appropriate perspective. On the way, he almost tripped over Yogi Berra.

title: Bronx Street of Violence; 10 Killings Sap Hope on Beekman Ave.
description: They fixed the basketball court, across a rubble lot from Beekman Avenue, in time for the tournament this summer. They patched the backboards, strung new nets from the smooth steel hoops. The players wore T-shirts printed with 21 names, the names of young men who have been killed near Beekman Avenue in the South Bronx over the last two years. Their average age was 18.

title: Review/Television; Teen-Agers Face Reality On Both Sides of Screen
description: Trying to attract more subscribers, Home Box Office has been noticeably more vigorous lately in its pursuit of original programming. Viewers obviously want something more than theatrical-release movies that they can already rent in video stores.

title: Etiquette for Handling Otherworldly Calls
description: ASTRONOMERS are already thinking about what they will do if one day their radio receivers should crackle with signals of a pattern that they think could only come from intelligent beings elsewhere in the universe.

title: A's, Eck and Etiquette, Dear Reader
description: While the American League playoff between the Blue Jays and Athletics continues, the verbal battle between pitchers Jack Morris and Dennis Eckersley is escalating.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: A NEW FEAR AMONG HEALTH WORKERS

title: Knick Rookie Delivers And Takes Orders, Too
description: Hubert Davis has decided to obey when Patrick Ewing asks him to do a rookie chore, such as carrying basketballs to practice.

title: Victory Brings No Delight For Brooks
description: Coach Herb Brooks of the Devils tonight demonstrated his unhappiness when his players neglected his concept of team play in favor of individualism, even with a three-goal lead in the third period.

title: Manila May Let Some U.S. Forces Stay
description: President Fidel V. Ramos of the Philippines said today that he was willing to accept the stationing of American troops in the Philippines even after the United States withdraws from its last major military base here.

title: Bacteria Are Found to Thrive on a Rich Social Life
description: "NO man is an island, entire of itself," John Donne wrote. Surprisingly, the same is now turning out to be true even for bacteria, the simplest of organisms. These single-celled creatures, long viewed as independent and self sufficient, nonetheless are endowed to lead a rich social life. They rarely live alone. They travel in packs, cooperate and are willing to be sacrificed so their fellows may survive. Some aggregate so closely as to mimic a multicellular organism. Others bind themselves together into a cluster for protection against an enemy.

title: California Draws On Ports' Profits
description: The State of California has found a sugar daddy to help bail it out of its financial hole. The State Legislature, facing a $10.7 billion budget gap, passed a measure last month that for the first time allows cities to draw on the profits of their ports, which have become the busiest, fastest-growing and most profitable in the nation.

title: Health Industry Gives Freely in Election
description: If the flow of money is any indication, health care promises to be a lively issue on Capitol Hill next year.

title: By Design; Dressing Alike
description: It's true that women are wearing men's ties. What's untrue is the rumor that skirts will catch on with men.

title: CPC International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $ 31.5 million from discontinued operations in the quarter and 9 months.

title: Chiat/Day/Mojo Given MTV Work
description: MTV Networks in New York yesterday named Chiat/Day/Mojo in New York to handle the Nick at Night, Nickelodeon and MTV cable television network accounts, with combined billings estimated to exceed $14 million. The accounts were previously handled by Fred/Alan in New York, which closed in June.

title: Trade Pact With Mexico Expected to Have Mixed Impact on Employers
description: In his 60 years as a garment maker in the New York region, Ralph Shomer has seen his share of competition from companies that have fled in search of cheaper labor.

title: Automotive Industries Holding Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-After a one-time extraordinary charge of $ 8,259,000 associated with the company's initial offering and related refinancing. Included were the write-off of prior debt issuance costs, a premium to exchange subordinated notes for new senior notes and interest rate swap termination costs.Automotive Industries Holding said that taking into effect the May 8 initial public offering and related refinancing, on a pro forma basis, year-ago third quarter net would be $ 3,070,000, or 19 cents a share, on revenues of $ 56,840,000. For the 9 months, income on a pro forma basis net would be $ 12,611,000, or 80 cents a share, on revenues of $ 197,645,000, compared with year-earlier net income of $ 7,318,000, or 46 cents a share, on revenues of $ 150,024,000.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Street Litter in Time Fouls New York's Waters
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: European players have long suffered from a small delusion: They refer to the Grand Slam Force as a "Josephine," in the belief that it was invented by Josephine Culbertson. The inventor was her husband, Ely Culbertson, who allowed her to claim the credit.

title: Coslet: Piqued, Puzzled, Patient
description: In somber remarks that reflected his team's dire straits, Coach Bruce Coslet said today that he was disheartened by a drop-off in intensity on the part of the Jets, compared with last year.

title: Westinghouse Credit Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 155 million provision for losses, $ 100 million of which pertains to investments in Phar-Mor Inc., and the settlement of the suit filed by a mutual fund related to its March purchase of Phar-Mor stock from Westinghouse Credit.c-Includes a $ 1.674 billion provision for losses, which reflected a reduction in the estimated realizable value of Westinghouse Credit's assets, primarily in the real estate portfolio.Westinghouse Credit, the principal unit of Westinghouse Electric Corp.'s Westinghouse Financial Services Inc., said that Phar-Mor Inc. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in August shortly after it disclosed an alleged fraud and embezzlement scheme by certain former members of its management. The remainder of its $ 155 million provision was an addition to credit reserves for other accounts.Losses for the latest third quarter and 9 months also reflected reduced interest margins, partially offset by equity gains for the 9-month period. Reduced revenues in the latest third quarter and 9 months were due to lower asset levels and lower yields due to a lower percentage of earning assets in the portfolio and reduced interest rates.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CLAIRE BLOOM was about to go to bed one night 17 years ago when she got a call from Halston, the fashion designer, summoning her to his home in Manhattan to meet Martha Graham.

title: Molex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Molex said that its latest first-quarter increase in revenues and net income reflected the effect of translating at generally higher overseas currency rates compared with the year-ago first quarter.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Both Czechs and Slovaks Must Rebuild
description: To the Editor:

title: Schuler Homes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months' net income, share earnings and shares outstanding are pro forma.The year-ago periods' results are pro forma, but with the exception of the sales figures.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Stock Offers Off in Quarter
description: The value of initial public stock offerings by nonfinancial companies dropped 58 percent, or more than $3.5 billion, in the third quarter to the lowest level since the first quarter of 1991, according to a survey released yesterday.

title: Weis Markets reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Loehmann's Cuts Losses
description: Loehmann's Holdings Inc., one of the country's oldest retail chains, said yesterday that its second-quarter loss narrowed from a year ago, even though sales were lower.

title: Board Is Said To Warn G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation's outside directors have urged the company's chairman, Robert C. Stempel, to stand up to the United Automobile Workers' union and to step up the pace of streamlining the company or risk losing his own job, perhaps by the end of the year, The Washington Post reported in today's issue.

title: MICROSOFT TO OPEN FOUR UNITS IN EASTERN EUROPE
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it would be the first software company to open wholly owned subsidiaries in four Eastern European nations. Four of Microsoft's best-selling programs will be translated into Russian, Czech, Polish and Hungarian through these new units by the second quarter of 1993, the company said.

title: Franklin Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Included extraordinary tax-loss carryforwards of $ 23,000 in the quarter and $ 120,000, or 2 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-Included extraordinary tax-loss carryforwards of $ 23,000 and $ 112,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Man Charged in Stabbing of Son
description: A 19-year-old Brooklyn man trying to prevent his father from driving while intoxicated was stabbed and critically injured yesterday afternoon, and the police later charged the father with the assault. Neighbors -- some of whom witnessed the stabbing -- called it a tragedy in a decent family.

title: Why a Hunter Uses An Assault Rifle
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday describing the scene surrounding the Presidential debate rendered a quotation from Bill Clinton incorrectly. Referring to his half brother, a recovering drug addict, Mr. Clinton said, "If drugs were legal, I don't think he'd be alive today"; Mr. Clinton did not say "illegal."

title: Music Notes
description: Musical Umbrella

title: McCarver Can't Keep a Knuckleballer Straight
description: Tim McCarver has labored through a curious mental block during the National League Championship Series. Seems he can't get a retired, cup-of-coffee pitcher named Bill (not Tim) Wakefield out of his mind when referring to Pirates knuckleballer Tim (not Bill) Wakefield.

title: Observer; All Joy Departed
description: While fending off coma during the Presidential "debate" Sunday night, I reached for the restorative memory of Franklin Delano Roosevelt but couldn't grasp it. The previous week had been too depressing.

title: Amdahl Will Lay Off 9% of Its Work Force
description: The Amdahl Corporation, the troubled mainframe computer maker, said today that it would lay off 900 workers, or about 9 percent of its work force, next month.

title: No. 2 in Arkansas Is Planning Transition to No. 1
description: Some fear a jinx. Others want to avoid the appearance of being presumptuous. Whatever the reason, it is hard to find anyone in the state Capitol here eager to discuss their plans for Nov. 4. Other than Jim Guy Tucker, that is.

title: Seville Journal; It Was a Nice Fair (Just Don't Mention Columbus)
description: Organized as the central event of Spain's celebration of the Columbus quincentenary, the World's Fair in Seville ended today much as it began six months ago -- with barely a word of thanks to the man who made the $2.2 billion extravaganza possible.

title: TB, Easily Transmitted, Adds a Peril to Medicine
description: Dr. John Norris recalls a recent patient in his walk-in clinic at University Hospital in Newark who listed his complaints as weight loss, cough and blood-tinged sputum. Today these symptoms, the classic signs of tuberculosis, strike new fears in doctors and nurses, prison guards and those who help the poor and homeless.

title: SynOptics Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Rave Reviews as Handley Is Finally Roaring
description: It was only one play in a game that lasted almost three hours. But it showed a side of Ray Handley that many people do not usually see -- raw, emotional anger. The crowd loved it and his players loved it. Today, Handley himself seemed pleased by it.

title: Computer Data Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Bellwether County; Bellwether County Gravitates To Clinton, if Only by Default
description: In the high desert country of Crook County, a tie is something that looks like a shoelace, Ross Perot haircuts never went out of style and the gas station serves dog biscuits for your pet while you wait. It may not seem like the rest of America, but in the last 27 Presidential elections this place has been an uncanny mirror of the national mood.

title: Print Shop Program Changes And Grows
description: THE PRINT SHOP has been around for nearly nine years, an age as computer programs go, producing greeting cards, signs, banners, letterheads and calendars for school and club, home and small business. In that time, it has evolved as computers and printers have advanced from the early systems with slow displays and crude output to today's hot rods.

title: ShowBiz Pizza Time Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Police Board: Seeking Compromise
description: After weeks of unexpected progress, negotiations over an all-civilian police review board for New York City are at a standstill, thwarted by differences over who appoints board members -- the mayor alone or the mayor and the City Council. The only sensible solution is compromise. If political leaders remain inflexible, they will risk further inflammation.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: On My Mind; Mr. Bush Steps Aside
description: Months ago, even before the embarrassing Republican Convention, a number of important Republican politicians, thinkers and money-raisers began saying that President Bush should step aside and let some other Republican get a crack at the White House -- somebody who could win.

title: Where Have All the Monarch Butterflies Gone?
description: EVERY fall millions of reddish-brown and black monarch butterflies move southward across the United States to the lush fir forests in Mexico, where they spend the winter. But this year some of the normally crowded migration routes are nearly empty.

title: Review/Pop; The Past Without Nostalgia
description: With her band plinking and fiddling an old mountain tune, Michelle Shocked stood onstage at Carnegie Hall on Friday night and, like a square-dance caller, led the audience in "chair dancing." After telling the audience to lean left and right, forward and back, she instructed, "Put your hands in the air, and wave 'em like you just don't care" -- a ritual of hip-hop.

title: Clayton Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Whitney Holding reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: China Leaders Stress Both Market and Orthodoxy
description: The Chinese Communist Party opened its 14th congress today with a call for an economic "revolution," linking the country's future to the development of a market economy and placing priority on economic growth rather than ideology. But the key speech at the gathering made clear that the party wants free markets only for goods and services, not for ideas.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT SIMMS, a 29-year-old security guard at Madison Square Garden, has filed a harassment complaint against ELTON JOHN, accusing the singer of striking him on the head and neck in the middle of a concert on Friday evening.

title: Review/Television; Multiple Splits on Clarence Thomas
description: From the start, Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court divided white liberals from many of their accustomed allies in black America. As tonight's plain-talking "Frontline" documentary reports, the N.A.A.C.P. was "conflicted and paralyzed": the civil rights organization disagreed with Judge Thomas's record in almost every particular, yet some of its leaders were reluctant to oppose a black man. Democratic senators who would ordinarily have gone on the attack against so conservative a Bush Administration nominee held back for fear of opening themselves to charges of racism.

title: Police Officer Hurt By a Passing Truck
description: A police officer trying to push back a crowd of spectators at the Columbus Day Parade in Manhattan yesterday was injured when he was struck by the side-view mirror of a truck as it entered a midtown intersection, the police said.

title: Kaydon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Patterns
description: London's Lot in '93

title: 'Creatures' Get a Life
description: THE idea of artificial life probably goes back further than the golem or Frankenstein's monster, but only recently has it gained wide attention in the computer and biological sciences. Basically, artificial life concerns "creatures" -- computer instructions, or pure information -- that are created, replicate, evolve and die as if they were living organisms.

title: INDIANS IN PROTEST AGAINST COLUMBUS
description: Up and down Latin America today, the 500th anniversary of Columbus's arrival in the Americas was marked by tight security around Spain's embassies and by calls for cultural renewal by Indian peoples.

title: Despite G.O.P. Attacks, Florio Edges Up in Polls
description: Republican attack ads about Jim Florio have become something of a cliche in New Jersey.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING November Snow Wins

title: Law Expected to Squeeze Refiners
description: For years refiners have worried about how much they pay for the crude oil they buy, how much they can get for the products they sell and whether the difference between the two leaves them a profit. But their lives are about to become substantially more complicated, because of new laws that force changes in the composition of oil products.

title: Corrections
description: A calendar entry in "This Week" in the Long Island Weekly on Sunday about a rally against breast cancer gave an incorrect date. The rally is at 11:45 A.M. today, not on Thursday, outside State Supreme Court in Mineola.

title: KUWAITIS WILL BUY TANKS MADE IN U.S.
description: Kuwait has agreed to buy 236 advanced battle tanks built in Michigan and Ohio, instead of British-made tanks, after President Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney personally intervened with the Kuwaiti royal family, Administration officials said today.

title: Dinkins Narrows Plan for Improving Taxi Service
description: Retreating from a plan to fundamentally reorganize New York City's taxi industry, Mayor David N. Dinkins has prepared a more modest proposal to improve cab service outside the Manhattan business districts.

title: Texas Utilities Co.  reports earnings for 12mos Sept 30
description: b-Included $ 80 million from unbilled base rate revenues outstanding Dec. 31, 1991 and $ 38 million of additional income related to unbilled revenue Sept. 30.c-Net loss and included net after-tax charges of $ 1.048 billion for disallowances.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article yesterday about Sunday night's Presidential debate omitted a passage in some copies. The affected paragraph should have read: "Mr. Clinton and Mr. Perot offered similar visions of the nation's post-cold-war needs: to rebuild the country's financial strength, reduce the former superpowers' nuclear arsenals and help promote democratic societies, especially in the Soviet Union."

title: A.T.& T. and Mitsubishi Settle Phone Suit
description: A.T.& T. and the Mitsubishi International Corporation said yesterday that they had agreed to settle their legal dispute over the intrusion last year into Mitsubishi's private United States telephone system by computer "hackers" who made thousands of illegal long-distance calls.

title: Spec's Music Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Senate Panel Will Question Feuding Officials in Iraq Bank Case
description: Senator David L. Boren said today that the Senate Intelligence Committee would begin taking sworn statements this week from Central Intelligence Agency and Justice Department officials regarding their handling of a politically sensitive bank fraud case involving Iraq.

title: Electronic Arts reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Hey Aleksei, Welcome to the N.H.L.
description: Aleksei Kovalev had never seen anything like this. Sure the lights and laser show prior to last night's Rangers' home opener were a bit daunting. And the Madison Square Garden crowd noise, he said, was greater than what he'd heard at all his Russian games combined.

title: Two Towns Use Different Tactics to Fight Beach Erosion
description: As two of the metropolitan area's most eroded oceanfront communities, this splinter of a coastal town and the town of Westhampton Beach, L.I., have much in common. But they could hardly be further apart when it comes to staving off the sea.

title: Frank Mercurio, 80, an Enforcer Of Labor Laws for Four Decades
description: Frank B. Mercurio, a longtime enforcer of labor laws, died on Saturday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: Bill T. Jones Thinking Small This Season
description: Bill T. Jones stretches like a cat in the sunshine on the plaza outside the Harlem theater where his company is rehearsing. Barefoot with thin, crisp braids tumbling from his head, Mr. Jones looks like anything but a hardheaded, indefatigable producer of dances. But that is what he is.

title: Latin Bishops Reopen Debate on Church Role
description: Pope John Paul II opened a major meeting of Latin American bishops today that was called to assess the Roman Catholic Church's work in the region, including its deep involvement in social and economic issues.

title: De Klerk Insists on Security for Whites, Suggesting Extended Debate
description: President F. W. de Klerk, beset by critics from across the political spectrum, vowed today that his Government would not surrender power until the security of the white minority had been firmly entrenched.

title: Executive Changes
description: CYPRESS SEMICONDUCTOR CORP., San Jose, Calif., named Pat Verderico vice president of administration and chief financial officer. HPSC INC., Boston, a unit of Healthco International that leases dental equipment, named Raymond R. Doherty chairman and chief executive.

title: Clinton's Vietnam Era Compatriots at Oxford; Divisive and Peripheral
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton's Vietnam Era Compatriots at Oxford; What of Bush's Sons?
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Fashion; In London, Clothes for Real Life
description: No mad careering down old hippie highways for designers here. They packed their spring and summer fashion shows into a long weekend from Saturday to Monday and kept their eyes resolutely on the future. The revival of fashions from the 60's and 70's was cheerfully left to the Italians, who examined the period exhaustively in their shows in Milan last week.

title: Conagra Share Offer
description: Charles M. Harper, the chairman of Conagra Inc., will sell about 40 percent of his common shares in the company, Conagra said today. Mr. Harper owned 2.5 million shares as of July 31, according to Conagra's August proxy statement. The food company has about 245 million common shares outstanding. The timing of the sale has not been determined. At today's closing price of $30.125 a share, the sale of 40 percent of Mr. Harper's holdings, or more than a million shares, would bring in more than $30 million. The Conagra chairman is selling the stock to pursue "personal business investments and commitments," the company said.

title: Astronomers Start Search For Life Beyond Earth
description: On the day marking that fateful landfall of Columbus 500 years ago, introducing America into world history, astronomers began searching the heavens for other new worlds, where there may dwell civilizations thriving in the warmth of other stars.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week; Clinton Basks in Glow Of Easy Lead in Race
description: In readying their candidate to debate George Bush, the advisers to Bill Clinton prepared for the worst. In mock debate sessions that lasted hours, the men playing the President and the panelists hit the Democratic candidate with hard and sometimes brutal questions about his draft record, his marriage, his honesty and his patriotism.

title: Joseph Toy Curtiss, 91, Member Of Yale Faculty for Four Decades
description: Joseph Toy Curtiss, a member of the Yale University English faculty for nearly four decades, died Sunday at his home in Simsbury, Conn. He was 91 years old.

title: F.B.I. CHIEF'S TRIPS PROMPT AN INQUIRY
description: William S. Sessions, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, is under scrutiny in a Justice Department ethics review of his travels aboard official aircraft, Government officials said today.

title: Motorola Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Issues -- The Environment; Clinton and Bush Show Contradictions in Balancing Jobs and Conservation
description: Both President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton say promoting economic growth is just as important as protecting the environment. But the two candidates clearly differ on how the Government should be used to set priorities and promote these goals.

title: Shaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Classical Music in Review
description: Santiago Rodriguez Pianist 92d Street Y

title: Study Ties Genes to Drinking In Women as Much as in Men
description: WOMEN have as strong an inherited susceptibility to alcoholism as men, according to a report appearing today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Primerica Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included after-tax net portfolio gains of $ 28.3 million, or 26 cents a share.c-Included in income from operations in the 9 months ended Sept. 30, 1991, are after-tax charges of $ 10 million related to restructuring of the Specialty Life and Health operations and $ 15.6 million related to real estate lease commitments.The results included 60 cents in the latest 9 months, and 23 cents in the year-ago period, relating to gains on sales of stock of subsidiaries and affiliates.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: MANY-a-True-Word Department: Kate Frank Cohen was in Brooks Brothers poised for the annual outfitting of her teen-age son.

title: Sherwin-Williams reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Woolly Bear Weathermen
description: Though appealingly fuzzy, it hardly makes a fashion statement: two bands of black and one of brown, the comfortable brown of a beloved sweater. After a summer spent munching grass and leaves, the woolly bear caterpillar is walking now -- all over country roads, across decks and patios, around stone walls and piles of wood.

title: Telco Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.Telco said that fiscal 1992 included 53 weeks, compared with 52 weeks in the 1991 fiscal year.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: In Dispute; Quayle and Gore Battle Devolves Into a Hand-to-Hand Fight About 4 Issues
description: While Vice President Dan Quayle and Senator Al Gore argued across a broad spectrum of issues in the Vice-Presidential debate this evening, they conducted the verbal equivalent of hand-to-hand combat over four specific points.

title: Justices Show No Support For Reviewing Flag Issue
description: If anyone is going to reignite the legal and political battle over burning the American flag, it will evidently not be any current member of the Supreme Court.

title: Froelich Rainey, 85, A Museum Director And an Archeologist
description: Froelich G. Rainey, an archeologist, museum director and creator of an award-winning television program, died on Sunday at a hospital in Cornwall, England. He was 85 years old and lived in Cornwall.

title: Genicom Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 1,273,000, or 12 cents a share, which reflects the cumulative purchase of $ 4 million principal amount of the company's notes.c-Net lossd-After an extraordinary credit of $ 1,442,000, or 14 cents a share, from the company's open market purchases of $ 5 million principal amount of its 121/2 percent senior subordinated notes for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $ 3,691,000, or 35 cents a share, which reflects the cumulative purchase of $ 13.3 million principal amount of the company's notes.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: No Excuse for Mr. Barr's Outrage
description: When House Democrats asked for an independent prosecutor to investigate aid given to Iraq before the Persian Gulf war, Attorney General William Barr was outraged. He sensed that political opponents were out to get him. But Mr. Barr asserted wrongly that his Justice Department was handling the case credibly. Its prosecution is unraveling in a welter of confusion.

title: Vote for Bush? Not U.S. Jews Now in Israel
description: If the Presidential election were in the hands of Americans living in this Jewish settlement near Bethlehem, President Bush could start packing his bags right now.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BILLY FRANK JR., who was arrested more than 40 times for his efforts in behalf of American Indian fishing rights in the Pacific Northwest, was awarded the Albert Schweitzer Prize for Humanitarianism yesterday at Johns Hopkins University.

title: Personal Health
description: BREAST cancer is the disease women fear most. Nearly every woman over the age of 45 is acquainted with at least one woman her age who has developed breast cancer. And reports like the recent one that raised to a woman's lifetime risk of developing breast cancer one chance in eight do little to quell mounting fears that new cases are outpacing progress in early diagnosis and treatment of this most common life-threatening cancer in American women.

title: Lukens Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: The company said all share results reflect a 3-for-2 stock split of Sept. 28.

title: A Very Familiar Sound
description: San Franciso may not be done with the Giants quite yet. A group of local investors showed up on the doorstep of the National League's president, BILL WHITE, on Monday with a $95 million bid to buy the Giants and keep them in San Francisco. PETER A. MAGOWAN, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Safeway, heads the investors, who were assembled by WALTER H. SHORENSTEIN, chairman of the Shorenstein Company.

title: Bank Yields Drop a Bit In Week
description: Yields offered on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit edged lower in the week ending today. But the decline for yields on certificates of deposit was not as steep as the drops in money market accounts.

title: Nycor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gain of $ 3,859,000 in the first quarter from the sale of Zenith Electronics Corp. common stock, in the quarter; the 9 months included gain of $ 4,353,000 from the sale of Zenith stock, less $ 1,9196,000 in deferred costs associated with Nycor's 1991 proxy contest, for a net gain of $ 3,156,000.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Cypress Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: News Analysis; Quayle on the Offensive
description: Vice President Dan Quayle may be no Jack Kennedy, but he was no stumblebum either in the second of the 1992 campaign debates last night.

description: b-Included a gain of $ 91,000, or 1 cent a share, from cumulative effect of change in income tax accounting.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

description: Following are excerpts from the Vice-Presidential debate in Atlanta last night between Vice President Dan Quayle, Senator Al Gore and James B. Stockdale, as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: Cognex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: American List reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Nycor Has Higher Net
description: Nycor Inc. said today that its third-quarter net income rose to $5.28 million, or 69 cents a share, from $962,000, or 7 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Results for the recent quarter include a gain of $3.86 million from the sale of Nycor's stake in the Zenith Electronics Corporation. Nycor, a holding company, did not record any revenue in the recent and year-ago quarters. Interest and other income rose to $5.94 million from $1.45 million. In over-the-counter trading today, Nycor shares lost 18.75 cents each, closing at $2.3125.

title: Profit Is Posted by Borland
description: Borland International Inc., one of the biggest publishers of spreadsheet and data base software, today reported second-quarter earnings of $5.4 million, or 20 cents a share, compared with a loss of $103 million in the corresponding period last year.

title: Jurors Consider Murder Charge Against Motorman in '91 Crash
description: A Manhattan jury has begun weighing the fate of Robert E. Ray, the subway motorman who is charged with murder in the deaths of five people in a massive subway crash last year. Mr. Ray, who prosecutors assert was drunk at the controls, was portrayed by the defense as the victim of a terrible accident.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Monday about "You Could Be Home Now," Ann Magnuson's one-woman show at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, misidentified the set designer. He is Bill Clarke, not Bill Stabile.

title: Bosnian Serbs' Forces Agree to Grounding of Military Planes
description: In response to the Security Council ban on military flights over Bosnia, Serbian forces there agreed today to send their military aircraft to airfields under United Nations supervision so they cannot be used in further fighting.

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Syracuse

title: Market Place; Confusion About A Day in Court
description: IF a lawsuit filed by a public company is worth crowing about when it is filed, one might think it would be equally of note when it is withdrawn or amended. But that is not, apparently, the modus operandi of executives at Alco International Group Inc., a San Diego cargo-hauling and medical-products company that has been in a nasty tiff with short-sellers.

title: Theater in Review
description: Fortinbras Kampo Cultural Center 31 Bond Street Lower East Side Through Nov. 1 By Lee Blessing; directed by Jeanne Blake; set design, David Birn and Judy Gailen; costumes, Teresa Snider-Stein; assistant costumer, Jonathan Green; lighting, Jeffrey S. Koger; production stage manager, Dean Gray. Presented by Signature Theater Company, James Houghton, artistic director. WITH: William Cain, Kevin Elden, Steven Guevera, Celia Howard, Albert Macklin, Archer Martin, Samantha Mathis, William Metzo, Keith Reddin, Don Reilly, Anthony Michael Ruivivar, Josh Sebers, Kim Walsh and Timothy Wheeler.

title: New Nobel Laureate Takes Economics Far Afield
description: Gary S. Becker of the University of Chicago has been awarded the 1992 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science. It was the third economics Nobel in three years for the university, whose policy-oriented economists have had an immense impact on the profession in the last half-century.

description: b-Net loss

description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 479,000, or 3 cents a share.c-Net lossThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Theater in Review
description: The Caretaker Jean Cocteau Repertory Bouwerie Lane Theater 330 Bowery (at Second Street) Lower East Side Through Dec. 10 By Harold Pinter; direction and lighting design by Eve Adamson; set design by John Brown; costumes, Ofra Confino; production manager, Patrick Heydenburg; stage manager, Jonathan R. Polgar. Presented by Jean Cocteau Repertory, Scott Shattuck, managing director. WITH: Harris Berlinsky, Joseph Menino and Craig Smith.

title: General Electric's Earnings Rose 6.7% in Third Quarter
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that its profits increased 6.7 percent in the third quarter in part because of improved productivity and gains from its financial, medical and aerospace divisions. The results were tarnished, however, by restructuring charges and losses at its NBC television network because of the 1992 Olympics.

title: Avesis Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Debate; Quayle and Gore Exchange Sharp Attacks in Debate
description: In a debate marked by intensely personal exchanges, Senator Al Gore and Vice President Dan Quayle delivered some of the campaign's strongest blasts last night, each asserting that the opposing Presidential candidate did not deserve to lead the nation for the next four years.

title: Union to Resume Talks With News's Suitor
description: Under pressure from other unions eager to cement labor agreements for a pending sale of The Daily News , the Newspaper Guild will resume talks today with the bankrupt paper's likely buyer, Mortimer B. Zuckerman , union leaders said last night.

title: Swastika Etched on Wall
description: A swastika was discovered yesterday morning etched into a wall in the lobby of a Brooklyn apartment building, Mayor David N. Dinkins said in a statement. It was the fourth time in a week that a swastika had been daubed on a New York City building and the eighth anti-Semitic incident in the city in recent days. In the most recent incident, a swastika was carved at 28 Old Fulton Street in Brooklyn Heights sometime between 7:30 P.M. Monday and 7:30 A.M. yesterday, Mayor Dinkins said. The Mayor, who said that about a third of the building's residents were Jewish, noted that the incident had occured during a Jewish holiday, Succoth.

title: Rome Journal; The Other Face of Italy: Its Busy Soup Kitchens
description: Alongside the designer stores and restaurants, the fountains and palaces, Rome has always had its underclass of hungry and homeless, those who came and saw and usually failed to conquer anything but a slice of sidewalk for a bed, a scoop of hand-out pasta for a meal.

title: Alcan Aluminium Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included net after-tax charges of $ 31 million largely related to the implementation of cost and productivity improvement programs.Results are in U.S. dollars.Revenue represented sales, operating revenues and other income.

title: Team Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 497,000 from discontinued operations.

description: Ten questions for the second Presidential debate, based upon an exhaustive study of the first:

title: Teen-Ager Indicted in Attack on Officers
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager was charged yesterday in connection with a baseball-bat attack on two New York City correction officers earlier this month.

title: Outlook Cut For Growth
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has cut its forecast for economic growth for its 24 industrial member countries to 2.1 percent in 1993 from the 3 percent growth rate it forecast in June.

title: Noland Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: A U.N. TEAM SEEKS TO DEFUSE ANGOLA
description: In the face of growing evidence that Angola's main opposition group is preparing for renewed fighting, a special delegation from the United Nations Security Council warned tonight that "any resumption of armed conflict will be met with the strongest condemnation of the international community."

title: BMC West Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: The company said that its earnings-per-share performance was affected by 43 percent increase in outstanding common shares following its initial public stock offering in August 1991.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Review/Television; Cuban Exiles and U.S. Policy on Castro
description: The threat by the Cuban American National Foundation to sue everybody involved in the production of "Campaign for Cuba" will not seem out of character to viewers of this investigative documentary. It can be seen at 10 tonight on Channels 13 and 49. The Miami-based foundation, the most important Cuban emigre group, is pictured as a muscular organization with a record of cracking down on those who differ with its hard-line anti-Castro doctrine.

title: Jets Decide to Stand Pat As Trade Deadline Passes
description: The National Football League trading deadline passed at 4 P.M. yesterday without the Jets making any deals or moves. In other words, they stood pat with a team that has a 1-5 record, tied with Seattle for the second worst in the league.

title: Hovnanian Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Wells Rich Greene And Hefty Part
description: The Mobil Chemical Company in Pittsford, N.Y., and Wells Rich Greene BDDP in New York said Monday that they had mutually decided to part ways on the Hefty trash bags account after eight years, because of creative differences. The companies declined to disclose the billings, but Adweek estimated them at $9 million.

title: Review/Opera; Philip Glass Offers More Than Memorial Just to Columbus
description: When the Metropolitan Opera takes the step of commissioning an opera to commemorate the 500th anniversary of Columbus's arrival in the New World, it is not offering an invitation to modesty and caution. So it should be no surprise that Philip Glass's opera "The Voyage," which received its world premiere at the Met on Monday night, can be accused of neither. It lasts nearly three and a half hours, cost more than $2 million and has something for everybody: a mixture of comforting cliche and aggressive pretense, some bombastic insistence and some tender, lyrical music that is among Mr. Glass's best. The production also has enough in it to keep the eyes occupied when the mind is not.

title: SI Handling Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: Year-ago periods' share earnings were restated to reflect 10 percent stock dividend issued Nov. 4, 1991.

title: Lazare Kaplan International reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 260,000, or 4 cents a share.c-Net loss

title: Standard Set for New Radio Technology
description: After more than a year of fidgeting and fussing over technical standards, electronics companies may soon give the ordinary AM-FM radio some new pizzazz.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Surrounding Scene; Did Not, Did So: Debate Offers Proof Young Are Better Seen Than Heard
description: As Epictetus, the Greek Stoic philosopher cherished by Admiral James B. Stockdale, once noted: "There are some faults which men readily admit, but others not so readily."

title: Hilton Hotels Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Specialty Retailers reports earnings for Qtr to Auig 1
description: There were no share earnings in year-ago periods after preferred dividends.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: ALONG with the term Provencal, the designation nicoise is prominent in the vocabulary of contemporary chefs. While both cooking styles are in vogue, they are certainly not new.

title: Left Holding the Bag in Iraq
description: The same Republican Administration that encouraged many American companies to do business with Iraq in the 1980's now treats them like pariahs. Instead of using Iraq's frozen assets in the U.S. to pay legitimate contract claims against Iraq by American companies, the State and Treasury Departments are using these assets to pay off foreign banks for Iraq's defaulted loans, despite timely warnings against doing so by Federal prosecutors investigating a multibillion-dollar bank fraud involving Iraq. The Government is also pledging some frozen Iraqi funds to the United Nations for aid programs.

title: Mapping Out Ethnic Foods, Freeway By Freeway
description: LIKE most Angelenos, Linda Burum was used to getting on the freeway and driving past every neighborhood except her own. But seven years ago, she gave up the fast track for smaller streets with meandering turns and traffic lights, streets that frequently lack signs. Her detours resulted in "A Guide to Ethnic Food in Los Angeles," which will be published this week by HarperPerennial.

title: Octel Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Honors
description: * David Tridle, president of the Frankel Services division of Frankel & Company, Chicago, was elected president of the Council of Sales Promotion Agencies, Stamford, Conn.

title: Power Failure Knocks Out 911 Phone Calls in Suffolk
description: For about two hours this morning, the more than one million residents of Suffolk County had no 911 emergency phone service, as a power failure in the New York Telephone switching station in Central Islip disabled the system.

title: Candidates on Television
description: The Presidential campaigners have scheduled these television appearances in coming days: Vice President Quayle

title: Brokerage Houses Report Strong Earnings
description: Merrill Lynch & Company and the Paine Webber Group reported strong third-quarter earnings yesterday, virtually insuring that 1992 will be a record year for profits on Wall Street.

title: Life Turns Bleak and Perilous In Serb-Held Area in Croatia
description: When Serbian forces carved out a swath of territory for themselves here last year, Serbs living under their protection felt euphoria and defiance. Many dared to think that their new homeland would eventually become part of a Greater Serbia extending throughout the Balkan region.

title: Sprint Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary charges of $ 5.6 million in the quarter from early extinguishment of debt and the effect of a change in accounting principle; the 9 months included a loss on the early extinguishment of debt and a gain on a change in accounting principle for extraordinary net of $ 30.8 million, or 14 cents a share.The latest 9 months' results included preferred stock dividend payments of $ 1.8 million, compared with $ 1.9 million in year-ago period.

title: Nassau County Government at Work: Details, Details at Center of Partisan Debate
description: How many government officials does it take to approve a light bill? In Nassau County, the answer depends on whether you ask a Republican or a Democrat.

title: ALLSTATE'S RATINGS LOWERED BY STANDARD & POOR'S
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday lowered its ratings on the claims-paying ability of the Allstate Insurance Company, a unit of Sears Roebuck & Company, and its property and casualty subsidiaries to AA- from AA+ because of the effects of Hurricane Andrew. S.& P. also downgraded rankings for Allstate Life Insurance and its subsidiaries to AA+ from AAA.

title: Sheriff Scolded for Acts in Teaneck Officer's Trial
description: Members of the Bergen County Sheriff's department improperly tried to influence the outcome of the trial of a white Teaneck police officer charged with killing a black teen-ager, state investigators said in a report released today.

title: New Rules on Pensions Are Adopted
description: Filling a void that had prevented many companies from offering a wide range of savings and pension plans to their workers, the Government adopted rules today protecting employers from lawsuits by employees disappointed with the return on their investment. The long-range intent of the new regulations is to encourage workers to exert more control over their investment and pension plans.

title: Chip Industry Indicator Off
description: Despite a slight increase in new orders, the semiconductor industry's leading indicator declined in September, a trade group reported today.

title: Net at Pfizer Increases 7.5%
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that third-quarter net income was about in line with expectations, rising 7.5 percent, to $297 million, or 88 cents a share, from $274.7 million, or 81 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Pentair Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Pentair said that the latest period benefitted, among other things from the September sale of its Delta International unit's Brazilian operation, and reduced tax rates on repatriated earnings.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

description: b-Included income of $ 17,281,000 from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Bonds Unchanged in Uncertainty
description: The bond market bounced around yesterday but ended little changed amid uncertainty over the election and the intentions of the Federal Reserve.

title: Romanian Chief Vows to Slow Economic Change
description: Ion Iliescu, the former high-ranking Communist who was re-elected President on Sunday, pledged today to keep the country's economic reform on course but at a reduced pace in order to cushion Romanians from the kind of shocks they have felt in the last two years.

title: Microsoft Net Rose 45.1% in First Quarter
description: The Microsoft Corporation reported first-quarter revenues and earnings today that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates.

title: Hughes Rudd, 71, TV Correspondent For Two Networks
description: Hughes Rudd, a former television correspondent for CBS News and ABC News noted for his deft, sardonic touch, died yesterday in a hospital in Toulouse, France. He was 71 years old.

description: To the Editor:

title: Pirates Throw Glavine a Curve in 8-Run Inning
description: Ken Saybel, who never pitched beyond Parsons College in Fairfield, Iowa, did a better job tonight than Phil Niekro, who pitched in the majors for 24 years.

description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: COMPANY NEWS: Employee Benefits; G.M. Executive Becomes Card-Carrying Celebrity
description: As a tool for motivating an employee, imagine the effectiveness of this approach: Hire someone to develop an important new product, spend more than $50 million to promote it and display the employee's name in large type in every piece of advertising.

title: Review/Film: The Public Eye; A Photographer Sees A City's Dark Side, But Not His Own
description: In "The Public Eye," set in 1942, Joe Pesci appears as a nervy, rude freelance photographer, Leon Bernstein, who's called Bernzy or the Great Bernzini by the editors and the cops with whom he deals. Bernzy has a way of arriving at the scene of a crime even before the police.

description: TERESA SEVERINI LUNGAROTTI was wearing her serious business face. She had just asked a visitor his opinion about a new wine.

description: b-Included a gain of $ 8.1 million from the arbitrated settlement of a contract dispute.c-Net loss and after a charge of $ 165,500,000 which reflects change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Pepsico Net Jumps 49.1% In 3d Period
description: Shrugging off the weak economy, Pepsico Inc. posted strong third-quarter profit gains in its soft-drink, potato chip and fast-food businesses.

title: South Korean to Run
description: The New York City Marathon has added a standout South Korean to its lineup for the Nov. 1 race. The runner, KIM WAN KI, has the seventh-fastest marathon time in the world this year (2 hours 9 minutes 31 seconds).

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stocks were higher here today. In the afternoon, the Nikkei index of 225 shares was up 33.6 points, or 0.19 percent, to 17,524.27. On Tuesday, the Nikkei gained 188.66 points.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: James Stockdale; Reluctant Politician Tempers Professional Edge
description: His hands shook with nerves. He stammered. He paused in the middle of his opening statement to put on his reading glasses. His snow-white forelock kept falling in his eye. He missed one question because his hearing aid was off.

title: Jacob H. Horwitz, 100, Innovator In Fashion and Hospital Founder
description: Jacob H. Horwitz, a fashion innovator who helped to create "junior miss" clothing and a philanthropist who was a founder of Long Island Jewish Medical Center, died on Sunday at his home in Lawrence, L.I. He was 100 years old.

title: Braves Use Old Knuckleballer for Aid in Facing a Young One
description: The thought was shocking. Phil Niekro, one of the granddaddies of all knuckleballers, said he could tell the Atlanta Braves something that could help them in their meeting tonight with Tim Wakefield of the Pittsburgh Pirates, the newest knuckleballer on the major league scene.

title: New Executive For Tropicana
description: Signaling plans for a major expansion of the Tropicana brand name onto other types of beverages, The Seagram Company Ltd., yesterday appointed Stephen B. Hughes, as executive vice president for the company's Tropicana Products Inc. subsidiary.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge related to the early retirement of debt of $ 2,000,000 for the quarter, and $ 6,000,000 related to the extinguishment of debt for the 9 months.c-After a charge of $ 215,000,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Corrections
description: The Political Week column yesterday, about Gov. Bill Clinton's campaign in the aftermath of the Presidential debate on Sunday night, referred to a Philadephia neighborhood incorrectly in some copies. The mostly poor, mostly black area he visited on Monday was in West Philadelphia; he also visited another neighborhood, South Philadelphia.

title: Laettner Deal Near?
description: The Minnesota Timberwolves are about to sign their No. 1 draft pick, CHRISTIAN LAETTNER, to a six-year deal for $20.1 million, according to a published report. The Star Tribune of Minneapolis reported yesterday that an unidentified league source said the Timberwolves have offered the former Duke star a deal that is worth $100,000 more than the six-year contract LARRY JOHNSON signed with Charlotte last year after being the first player selected in the 1991 draft.

title: Honeywell Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from early redemption of long-term debt of $ 5,500,000 for both the quarter and 9 months and the quarter and 9 months both included an after-tax gain of $ 91.6 million, or $ 1.32 a share, and $ 164 million, or $ 2.36 a share, respectively, from autofocus patent settlements.

title: New Forum for Bush On Character Issue
description: President Bush used a moment of political theater on a breakfast program to renew questions about Bill Clinton's antiwar activities during the Vietnam era and whether those efforts reflected on the Governor's ability to serve as President.

title: Dieting and Risk of Osteoporosis
description: A NORTH DAKOTA physiologist has found an unexpected reason why American women are unusually prone to osteoporosis, the bone disease: when they lose weight they also lose bone, even if they exercise regularly and consume adequate amounts of calcium while dieting.

title: Magnetic Technologies reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $ 301,000, or 30 cents a share, in the latest year and $ 114,000, or 11 cents a share, in year-ago period, both from tax loss carryforwards.

title: DISPUTE WITH JAPAN MAY AFFECT NEW PACIFIC ROUTE
description: United Airlines said yesterday that it might delay plans for a New York-Tokyo-Sydney route because of a dispute with the Japanese Government. Japan has rejected United's application for the flight, scheduled to begin Oct. 25. Japan wants restrictions on the number of seats that could be filled in Tokyo for the flight to Sydney to prevent competition with Japanese airlines. The carrier contends the new flight is explicitly authorized under the United States-Japan air agreement.

title: AT WORK WITH: Donny Deutsch; Portrait Of an Adman On a Hot Streak
description: THERE is a sign on a wall in the cluttered office of Donny Deutsch, the brash young adman who is among a handful of Madison Avenue professionals hired to help Gov. Bill Clinton try to become President Bill Clinton.

title: D'Amato Says He Has Plan For Arms-Plant Conversion
description: Saying the military spending cuts his opponent has proposed would devastate New York State's economy, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that he was working on a plan to offer a 50 percent tax credit to military contractors to encourage them to convert their plants to peacetime production.

title: Justice Dept. Criminal Unit Is Investigating F.B.I. Chief
description: An inquiry into the management and travel practices of William S. Sessions, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has escalated from an in-house ethics review to a preliminary criminal inquiry, Administration officials said today.

title: Eating Well
description: NO one, of course, will talk for the record. But the Food and Drug Administration and the United States Department of Agriculture are in one of their nastier cat fights over who best represents consumer interests. And off the record, they are happy to tell you why the other fellow is being stupid, stubborn, even venal.

title: SPS Transaction Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Henderson Steals a Bit of the Credit
description: While Dave Stewart was being widely praised for guaranteeing that the Athletics would win Game 5 of the American League Championship Series and then backing up his boast by pitching a complete-game seven-hitter in a 6-2 victory over the Blue Jays on Monday, Rickey Henderson did not mind assuming some of the credit, too.

title: Relief Aides Find U.S. Slow To Accept Balkan Refugees
description: Governments outside Europe are being asked to provide temporary housing for thousands of civilians being released from detention camps in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but refugee organizations say the plan is meeting resistance from the Bush Administration.

title: Israel Offering Aid to Victims
description: Israeli leaders, sending condolences to Egypt today, offered help to victims of the earthquake. There was no sign, however, that the offer had been accepted.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Becker Defeats Prpic Boris Becker of Germany, seeded third, had 13 aces yesterday to overpower Goran Prpic of Croatia, 6-4, 7-5, to advance to the third round of the Seiko Super tournament in Tokyo. Becker, ranked sixth in the world, broke Prpic's service in the ninth game of the first set and the 11th game of the second. Serving for the match, he won the final game at love, his fourth love game in the match on the artificial court of the Tokyo Metropolitan Gymnasium. The Americans Patrick McEnroe, Jonathan Stark, Jim Grabb and Richey Reneberg recorded first-round victories. McEnroe beat Christo Van Rensburg of South Africa, 6-3, 6-2. Stark defeated Grant Connell of Canada, 6-3, 6-4. Grabb edged Kenneth Carlsen of Denmark, 5-7, 7-6 (7-1), 6-2, and Reneberg beat Jacco Eltingh of the Netherlands, 3-6, 6-3, 6-2. (AP)

title: Walsh Has Stanford Team Looking Like 49ers
description: A squadron of Stanford students marched into the Rose Bowl on Saturday night chanting: "We've got Walsh. We've got Walsh."

title: A War of Slogans
description: The environment, abortion rights, America's cities -- issues that didn't even emerge in Sunday's Presidential debate -- finally surfaced in last night's free-for-all among the three Vice-Presidential candidates. But the disorderly proceedings defied deliberative discussion while encouraging diversionary tactics. The result was a war of slogans in which Dan Quayle emerged as the most artful and forceful of the sloganeers.

title: Officials Deny Racial Bias in Selecting Jury for '86 Trial
description: A fusillade of bullets that killed one police officer and gravely wounded another 11 years ago reverberated in a Queens courtroom yesterday as prosecutors defended having kept a dozen black men and women off the jury that convicted two black militants in the shootings.

title: Keene Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jays Won't Let Up After Letdown
description: The Toronto Blue Jays may have left an opportunity to clinch their first World Series berth on the field in Oakland yesterday. But they also left behind something else: the unwanted baggage of their past, having emerged from three games in Oakland still in great position.

title: One Minute to Doomsday
description: In October 1962, the Soviet Union, Cuba and United States came to the verge of military conflict and brought the world to the brink of nuclear disaster. None intended to create such risk. To understand what caused the crisis and how to avoid such risks, participants in the events have convened several times.

title: THEATER IN REVIEW
description: Empty Boxes Downtown Art Company 64 East Fourth Street East Village Through Sunday By William Badgett; directed by Kent Alexander; music by Harry Mann; lighting, Lenore Doxsee; stage manager, Ben Voorhies. Presented by Downtown Art Company, Ryan Gilliam, artistic director; Cliff Scott, producing director. WITH: The Talking Band.

title: Software Helps Patients Make Crucial Choices
description: Told by his doctor that he had an enlarged prostate gland, Richard A. Dronen, a 59-year-old retailing executive in Minneapolis, thought he should have surgery. His doctor, however, disagreed and sent Mr. Dronen to try a high-tech method of learning more about his prospects.

title: Polaroid Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27

title: Dinkins Urges Revisions In Taxi Plans
description: In formally announcing his plan to reorganize New York City's taxi industry yesterday, Mayor David N. Dinkins described a proposal that would make far fewer changes than he had originally planned in the hope of finally creating a consensus behind some form of change.

title: Topics of The Times; A Legal Lesson for V.M.I.
description: When the Justice Department sued the Virginia Military Institute for limiting its martial collegiate program to men, a Federal judge in Roanoke ruled for V.M.I. The school is "unique in all the world," he said, for its single-sex, physically rigorous, mentally stressful and oppressive regimen for training citizen-soldiers.

title: COMPANY NEWS>
description: BALL CORP., Muncie, Ind., said it had ended discussions with Eastman Kodak Co. about acquiring Kodak's image acquisition systems unit. UJB FINANCIAL CORP., Princeton, N.J., must face an investor lawsuit charging the bank holding company with fraudulently overstating its financial health. The United States Supreme Court yesterday rejected an appeal by UJB to scuttle the suit, which was filed after the company reported a large increase in delinquent loans and a quarterly loss in October 1990.

title: Dinkins's Deputy Mayor To Leave Administration
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins's chief political adviser, Bill Lynch, will not return to the administration after he finishes his stint as the deputy director of Gov. Bill Clinton's Presidential campaign in New York, city officials said yesterday. Instead, he will begin work as the director of the Mayor's re-election effort.

title: Koss Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Ad Campaign; Bush: Trying A Subtler Approach
description: The Bush campaign's newest advertisement, which was first broadcast on Monday, tries to avoid the criticism leveled at some previous commercials that they unfairly attacked Bill Clinton. ON THE SCREEN Opens with a white-on-black phrase, "Breakfast, St. Louis. After the debate." The buzz of conversation and the clinking of plates and silverware are audible in the background. The screen cuts to quick clips of eight people seated in booths at a restaurant. Each voices a concise opinion of Bill Clinton or Mr. Bush as a hand-held camera zooms in and out and rocks unsteadily. Closes with a small disclaimer, "Paid for by Bush-Quayle '92 General Committee Inc." PRODUCER The November Company THE SCRIPT First Man: "I saw the debate last night, and I just got one conclusion, It's all George Bush." First Woman: "I have, I still have a lot of confidence in my President."

title: RIVALS FOR SENATE PERSIST IN ATTACKS
description: The New York campaign for the United States Senate came to this yesterday: Robert Abrams said that when he called Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato a "fascist" on Sunday night, he had really meant to call him a "right-wing extremist." In either case, he stood by his assertion that the Senator was using the "big-lie techniques" of Nazi propagandists.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Off the Trail -- Visits With Americans; In Kentucky, a Local Legend Runs a Phantom-Like Campaign for Congress
description: Wispy as fog in the bottomland, there is a phantom campaign hereabouts being mastered by a quiet, punctilious Congressman who has never taken a political contribution in 39 years in the House and who drives the hilly Kentucky hustings alone, completely frustrating this year's sacrificial challenger.

description: Pressure is mounting for executives of the General Motors Corporation to take swifter, bolder action to stop further deterioration of the giant auto maker's ailing North American operations.

title: Finesse Trumps Fists In Debut by Kovalev
description: No one has to force Rangers Coach Roger Neilson to play a physical hockey game. Paul Holmgren, coach of the Hartford Whalers, amassed 1,600 penalty minutes during his 500-game Philadelphia Flyers career, so there's no need to ask how he feels about a little roughhousing on the ice. Heck, the metal gate in the Spectrum tunnel in Philadelphia was built to curb Holmgren's penchant for engaging in off-ice fights.

title: Ulysses Guimaraes, 'Grandfather' Of Brazilian Democracy, Is Dead
description: Ulysses Guimaraes, a veteran congressman often called the "grandfather" of Brazil's democracy, drowned on Monday when a helicopter in which he was flying fell into the South Atlantic about 100 miles south of here. He was 76 years old.

title: Greenspan Sees Risks Globally
description: In his first major speech since the currency crisis in Europe last month, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, has warned that global financial transactions may be too fast and too complex for senior bank managers to understand, and he called on governments to step up their supervision of international banks.

description: Share earnings are in units and are for class A depositary units.

title: MILLIONS IN ITALY MARCH IN PROTEST
description: Italy's big trade union federations called millions of workers into the streets of cities across the country today to protest the Government's economic austerity plan, which includes spending cuts, tax increases and the abolition of a decades-old system of linking wage increases to the rise in inflation.

title: Old Cairo: Ricketiness Killed Poor
description: Mohammed Aref, a police officer, held a plastic bag filled with odds and ends collected from the ruins of a 14-story apartment building, one of the few that collapsed in Heliopolis, a posh suburban district of northern Cairo.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; High Court to Rule on Admissibility Of Scientific Evidence in U.S. Courts
description: Opening the door to a far-reaching debate over the role of science in the courtroom, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide how widely accepted a scientific process or theory must be for it to be admissible as evidence in Federal court.
