description: To the Editor:

title: Serbs' Heavy New Artillery Attack Deprives Sarajevo of Its Flour Mill
description: Sarajevo appeared to have lost the use of its only flour mill today after heavy artillery attacks, a potentially serious blow to a city where many of the 400,000 residents have survived for months on a diet consisting mostly of bread and pasta.

title: For Baseball, the Worst of Times May Come After the Best of Seven
description: October heroics have a way of wiping from memory even the most rancorous disputes that can tarnish a baseball season. But this year more than most, public and private battles over such issues as Japanese ownership, the powers of the commissioner, National League realignment and escalating economic problems have detracted from developments on the field.

title: Ashe Benefit Raises Money and Laughter
description: Looking gaunt but graceful, ARTHUR ASHE, the AIDS-stricken tennis legend and one of the founding fathers of the ATP Tour, was honored Saturday night in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., at a gala that also celebrated the 20th anniversary of the men's pro tour.

title: Clinton Health Plan Covers All Americans; Outcome Analysis
description: To the Editor:

title: New System For Futures
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission on Monday will consider the Chicago Board of Trade's request to begin an in-house electronic trading system for less-traded contracts.

title: Guatemalan to Fight On With Nobel as Trumpet
description: All of the dancing was over and most of the meetings with diplomats; the telephone had stopped ringing from places like London and Boston and Buenos Aires -- for the first moment, anyway, since Rigoberta Menchu won the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Review/Music; The Man Who Moved Rock Into a New Era
description: It looked like a benefit concert, kin to Live Aid or Farm Aid. For nearly four hours on Friday night at Madison Square Garden, stars of various magnitudes played one or two songs each before an audience of 18,200 people, whose tickets had cost $80 or $150. Television cameras swooped on cranes over the stage for a telecast in 68 countries, along with pay-per-view cable outlets in the United States, while rock radio stations across America broadcast the music. (The pay-per-view telecast is to be repeated tomorrow night at 9 P.M.)

title: Bridge
description: If in doubt, it pays to believe the opponents. If you suspect a psychic bid, the odds are that your suspicions are unfounded. If you suspect a tricky falsecard, remember that most defenders play normally.

title: The New China -- A Special Report.; Chinese Communism's Secret Aim: Capitalism
description: To listen to some Chinese, one of the best-kept secrets in the world is this: Here in the land of Mao, where red banners with propaganda slogans still dangle from tall buildings, Communism has collapsed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Gaston's Move Turns Toronto Right-Side Up
description: In guiding the Toronto Blue Jays into their first World Series, Cito Gaston had developed a reputation as a patient manager best suited to the American League's designated-hitter philosophy that eliminates much of the strategic moves forced upon National League managers.

title: Centura Banks reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rouben Ter-Arutunian, 72, Dies; Designed City Ballet 'Nutcracker'
description: Rouben Ter-Arutunian, a prolific designer for dance, opera, theater and television, died on Saturday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

title: Blue Jays Give the Braves a Taste of Their Own Medicine
description: Francisco Cabrera, meet Ed Sprague.

title: State Street Boston Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: 1st Bancorp (Vincennes, Ind.) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Sees Indication Makers of Telescope Hid Signs of Problem
description: Federal officials say a two-year inquiry has found evidence that the makers of the mirror for the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope hid important clues to the flaw that has crippled the most complex and costly scientific instrument ever put into space.

title: Lisa R. Furman, Eric S. Cott
description: Lisa Renee Furman and Eric Spencer Cott were married yesterday in New York. Don Robert Johnson, a senior leader at the New York Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the Stanhope Hotel.

title: BancTec Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Promoting a Line of Jeans And Helping the Homeless
description: CAN an apparel company lose its blues by urging shoppers to do the same?

title: INSIDE
description: Murder's Younger Face

title: FMS Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included write-downs on land held for development of $ 285,000 for the quarter and $ 985,000 for the 9 months.c-Included write-downs on land held for development of $ 1,202,000.FMS Financial said that its latest quarter included a gain of $ 55,000 on the sale of loans, compared with $ 68,000 in the year-earlier period. For the latest 9 months, the company reported a $ 245,000 gain on the sale of loans, compared with $ 193,000 for the year-earlier 9 months.

title: Horton Interception Puts Cowboys on Top
description: Cowboys 17, Chiefs 10

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: METRO DIGEST NEW YORK IS BACK ON TV, IN SPIRIT ANYWAY

title: Russians to Release A Million Recordings In Broadcast Archive
description: An archive of more than a million audio and video recordings, including concert and radio performances by many of the former Soviet Union's most renowned musicians and by Western artists and ensembles who toured there, is to be made available for the first time to American, European and Asian recording companies. The tapes are part of the library of Ostankino, the Russian State Television and Radio Company, formerly known as Gosteleradio. Except for a few recordings that were released by the state-run Melodiya record label and licensed abroad, the recordings have never been heard in the West.

title: D'Amato Reiterates Pledge Not to Run for Office Again
description: Yesterday, a day after declaring that his current re-election campaign would be his last bid for public office, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said that he would not run again because he was tired of people ascribing "petty partisan political motives" to his actions.

title: Economic Memo; Administration Is Playing Blame Game on Recession
description: In unceremoniously announcing last week that it would dump its three top economic policy makers, the White House tried to lay the blame for the worst four years of growth since the Great Depression on the President's lieutenants.

title: A Day After a Hard Battle, Fischer and Spassky Draw
description: After their monumental struggle in the previous game, Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky shadowboxed to an early draw yesterday in Game 22 of their exhibition chess match in Belgrade. The score remains: Fischer 8, Spassky 4. If Fischer should win two more games, $3.35 million of the $5 million total purse would be his; Spassky would get the remainder.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Independent; While Perot's Economic Plans Are Detailed, Other Positions Remain Vague
description: When it comes to slashing the Federal deficit and spurring the economy, Ross Perot has cooked up a meaty stew of specific tax increases, spending cuts and tax incentives. But when he moves into the noneconomic areas of public policy, he serves up ideas that might evoke a cry from a past Presidential election: Where's the beef?

title: Bailey Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: b-Included a charge of 4 cents a share related to the completion of tooling projects for both the quarter and year.c-Net loss

title: Bell Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago per share earnings and shares outstanding are not applicable; company went public on Dec. 20, 1991.Bell Bancorp said an additional $ 6.1 million provision is included in the 6 months, which was recorded during the first quarter of 1991. The provision was based on management's evaluation of the loan portfolio and its evaluation of the regulatory and general economic environment at the time, rather than a significant increase in loan delinquencies or deterioration in the asset portfolio.

title: Integrated Device Tech reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net loss and included pretax restructuring charge of $ 4,228,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Could it be that Dr. RUTH WESTHEIMER, the psychotherapist who has made her name dispensing advice on sex, is acquiring a new persona? Yes indeed, she said the other day, talking about herself in the third person. "She has been bitten by a bug and has a passion in her belly about doing documentaries."

title: Canonie Environmental Services reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 287,000 related to restructuring; and an after-tax charge of $ 935,000 in recognition of higher-than-anticipated costs on two major remediation projects for both the quarter and 6 months.c-Net incomeThe company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Mark Hawkins, 82, Humorist-Essayist Of the Human Race
description: Mark F. Hawkins, a humorist whose essays on human foibles spanned 50 years, died on Oct. 7 at the California Pacific Medical Center in San Francisco. He was 82 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: Paving a Long Road to a Fair Trial; Lawyers for the Poor Must Often Defend Themselves, Too
description: Ingrid Yurchenco was saying how glad she was that she had left the sales tags in the shirt and tie she bought at Kmart the other day. Her client had made a plea bargain and would not be needing them for a trial, so she got her money back.

title: Grand Forks Journal; Sect That Fled Czarist Russia Looks Homeward
description: The Hoodikoff family was at lunch after the Sunday prayer meeting at the Doukhobor community center in this town surrounded by crags of the Cascade Mountains 450 miles east of Vancouver.

title: Dance in Review
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company offered a slightly disappointing performance of "Night Journey" on Saturday evening, when three dancers stepped into roles for the first time during the company's weeklong season at City Center. The dance depicts Jocasta's dying vision of her meeting of Oedipus, whom neither recognizes as her son, and their long, doomed marriage. "Night Journey" does not look quite like other Graham ventures into mythology. But Terese Capucilli and Kenneth Topping, who took on the roles of Jocasta and Oedipus, failed to give the piece the Graham feel of something etched in flesh and stone.

title: No Headline
description: Anything that happens on the planet, short of Somalia, happens in New York. You never have a believability problem in New York. You can say there are pygmy serial killers and they're operating in New York and it would be believable." -- DICK WOLF, television producer. [ B3:4. ]

title: TV Tunes In to New York, Hollywood Style
description: Forget those decadent "Dallas" and "Dynasty" and "Falcon Crest" rich people of the 1970's and 1980's on television. Forget the never-never world of "Love Boat" and "Fantasy Island" and "Charlie's Angels." What's hot now, at least in television, are the gritty streets and the grittier characters of New York City.

title: Election Day Initiatives May Affect Bond Issues
description: In the tax-exempt bond market, traders and investors face political uncertainty even beyond the outcome of the Presidential election. At the state and local level, there are numerous spending and taxing initiatives that could affect the credit outlook for the state and local governments, which would have a major impact on bonds.

title: Environment One Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Woeful Giants Make Rams Look Tough
description: Good Giants? Bad Giants? How about awful Giants, for they were really awful today in an unexpected 38-17 rout by the Los Angeles Rams.

description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Book Vendors Shouldn't Have Any Sidewalk Privileges
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; A Fountain Of Youth For TV News Magazines
description: UNTIL this year, only age discrimination prevented the network's news magazine programs from being accepted as hits of equal stature with prime-time shows like "Roseanne" and "Cheers."

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Record; Arkansas Struggles to Deal With Rising Health-Care Costs for Poor
description: Even as Gov. Bill Clinton promises a sweeping expansion of health-insurance programs in his Presidential campaign, his own state is cutting health-care benefits for poor people and payments to doctors in its Medicaid program.

Sandra Stone, Christopher Haas
description: Sandra Ann Stone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Stone of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Christopher James Haas, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert D. Haas of Virginia Beach, Va. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at Tarrytown House.

title: 5 Years After Crash, A Different Market
description: Five years ago today, the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 508 points, or 22.6 percent, leaving panic and disorder in its wake. Since then, the face of Wall Street has been indelibly changed.

title:
ROWING;
Brown Disqualified in Eights
description: Brown University won and then lost the featured Championship Eight's title at the 28th annual Head of the Charles Regatta today on a placid Charles River.

title: Rev. Timothy Sheehan, Ex-U.S. Drug Agent, 53
description: The Rev. Timothy G. Sheehan, a Federal drug enforcement agent who became a priest and later managed the finances of the Diocese of Brooklyn, died on Saturday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens. He was 53 years old and lived in the diocesan chancery residence in Brooklyn.

title: Chinese Party Congress Replaces Nearly Half of Central Committee
description: The Communist Party replaced nearly half its Central Committee today, dismissing some hard-liners and generally choosing more educated and pragmatic members, as it closed a party congress dedicated to building a market economy.

title: Xilinx Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Storage Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
Northern States Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rabin's Best Chance
description: Although peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians are flagging and both sides think time may be running out, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin could make progress when scheduled talks resume Wednesday in Washington, if he wanted to. Both sides are ripe for compromise as never before. The Israeli right cannot avoid acquiescing in the cession of land; the Palestinians would even bypass the dream of statehood to get some.

title: Jazzing Up Lincoln Center
description: Jazz is the only musical art form to which the United States can lay exclusive claim, and New York City is its Mecca. Yet even in New York, jazz has been shunted into bars and music clubs that are inaccessible to families, and to the young.

title: Progressive Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WORLD SERIES: Notebook; Flag, If Not Jays, Was Upended
description: Major league baseball paid tribute to Canada before Game 2 of the World Series tonight, but Canadians were not exactly thrilled. Their flag was displayed upside down.

description: The bank is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Avemco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Union Planters Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Union Planters said that its latest third-quarter net earnings reflected pretax securities gains of $ 9.4 million for the sale of about $ 213 million of investment securities, a pretax increase in litigation reserves of $ 3 million.The period also reflected a $ 1.3 million pretax provision for losses on owned and leased facilities as a result of the consolidation of the executive commercial lending and trust functions of Union Planters National Bank from three facilities into a new headquarters building.

title: Latest Apple Bridges 2 Worlds
description: In his obsessive pursuit of a quarry known to pursuers simply as Bob W., the head of Apple Computer's portable computing division once sent a product manager to an industry trade show to surreptitiously videotape competitors' products.

title: Market Place; High-Stakes Debate on the Future of I.B.M.
description: On Wall Street, I.B.M. isn't just a company -- it's a religion with at least two rival theologies. One holds that the company is trapped in a cycle of inevitable decline, the other that I.B.M. is going through a wrenching transition but retains enormous strengths and the ability to come back.

title: Trade Talk Progress Expected
description: The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, met here today with her counterparts from the European Community, Canada and Japan, then said she expected a breakthrough in stalled world trade talks "in a matter of days."

title: Review/Television; Players, Witting and Not, in a Game of Chance
description: In the early 1980's, Christopher Hampton was invited by the Mark Taper Forum to write a play having something to do with Los Angeles. He brought in "Tales From Hollywood," a portrait of exiles from Nazi Germany who ended up in Hollywood in the 1930's and 40's. That play, judiciously trimmed by 50 minutes to two hours, now serves brilliantly to open -- at 9 tonight on Channel 13 -- a new season of public television's "American Playhouse."

title: What the President Knew
description: Asked once again whether he had known about "arms for hostages" before the Iran-contra scandal broke, President Bush said the other day: "Yes, and I've said so all along." He's given sworn testimony to that effect hundreds of times, he said.

title: Weyerhaeuser Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Included a charge of $ 61 million from an adjustment in accounting.The company said that its pretax earnings included $ 25 million as the result of a partial settlement of a lawsuit for the refund of federal income taxes.

title: 3 Teen-Agers Shot in Bronx Near a School
description: Two 14-year-old girls walking across an intersection and a 16-year-old boy standing nearby were shot outside a Bronx high school yesterday afternoon by an assailant who blazed away with a rifle or a shotgun and fled on foot.

title: Ann F. Friedlaender; Economics Professor, 54
description: Ann F. Friedlaender, an economist who was the first woman to become an academic dean at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. She was 54 years old and lived in Newton, Mass.

description: Ana Dujiman, a 29-year-old Muslim refugee, broke down in tears as she lugged her 15-month-old daughter over the last painful yards of a four-mile hike across the mountainside war front.

title: There Aren't Enough Minutes in a Game to Do the Rangers Justice
description: There are too many quality players on the Rangers, and not enough minutes in a hockey game. The resulting mathematics has made the early season painful for Coach Roger Neilson and for the players on the bubble.

title: Scientists Find Catchy Names Help Ideas Fly
description: MOST scientific names are dull and pedantic, and usually as impenetrable as the Latin in which Linnaeus named all species known to him. But recently a strange whimsy has started to creep in among the sesquipedalian prose of scientific journals. A few scientists are attaching catchy terms like "chaos" or "chaperone molecules" to the things they discover.

title: Irate Russians Demonize Traders From Caucusus
description: Confused by the loss of an empire and frustrated by an inflation rate that keeps emptying their pockets, many Russians have fixed their fear and anxiety on a convenient target: traders from the Caucasus who have virtually taken over the farmers markets in Moscow and other cities, offering a tantalizing array of roses, lemons, bananas, bootlegged caviar, eggplant, Bulgarian chickens and other goods at prices beyond the average shopper's reach.

description: There will be many winners come Election Day, but it is already clear who the big losers in politics are this year.

title: Hit Series' Producers Must Scramble to Fill A Dead Actor's Role
description: One week after the sudden death of an actor with a central role in CBS's comedy hit series "Love and War," the creators of the program are shaken and puzzled about how to proceed.

title: Stone Age Art Shows Penguins at Mediterranean
description: FRENCH divers have discovered a partly flooded cave filled with prehistoric rock paintings and engravings, a great underground amphitheater studded with running horses, bison and deer as well as images of human hands believed to have been drawn some 18,000 years ago.

title: Plans for 14 Theme High Schools Begin Taking Shape in New York
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez's plan to create small alternative high schools began to take shape yesterday with a decision to give planning grants for 14 proposals to groups including unions, church organizations and colleges.

title: Johnson Adds to Total Of Games He'll Play
description: Magic Johnson is feeling so spry, he said today that he likely will buck doctor's orders and play several back-to-back games for the Lakers this season.

title: Dinkins and Council Trying to Craft Compromise on Review Board
description: The Dinkins administration and City Council leaders are trying to hammer out a compromise on the last major sticking point in structuring an all-civilian board to review charges of police misconduct: who would appoint the board members.

title: Sports of The Times; The Smell In the Giants' Locker Room
description: THE Giants' locker room yesterday afternoon smelled just as it normally does. Not exactly like perfume. The nostrils of visitors, though, were particularly acquiver at this time because a player on the team, linebacker Steve DeOssie, said after Sunday's miserable 38-17 loss to the Los Angeles Rams that the team had developed a certain scent. "We stink," he said.

title: Review/Dance; Graham Group Renews Long-Forgotten Works
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company ended a splendidly danced season on Sunday night at the City Center. Graham received a fine tribute from her dancers through this high quality of performance. A more formal homage is planned for 1994, when the company will celebrate the centennial of Graham's birth.

title: Does Our Society Have No Value Higher Than Tolerance?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reebok Earnings Rise 12%
description: Reebok International Ltd. today reported lower-than-expected earnings for the third quarter and said it expected results to remain disappointing through the end of the year.

MARY McFADDEN announced yesterday that she is rescinding an invitation to the Irish singer for the showing of her spring and summer collection at the New York Public Library on Nov. 5.

The net result was a gain of about $ 100,000, or 1 cent a share.The latest 9 months included three nonrecurring items which added a total of about $ 2.6 million, or 25 cents a share, to net income. In the second quarter, the company reported the settlement of a federal tax examination for 1985, 1986 and 1987, which produced a positive tax adjustment of $ 3.4 million.Also in the second quarter, the company reported the write-off of about $ 900,000 after tax, related to the production of a feature film. title: AMBASE IN DEAL TO SELL 80% OF CARTERET SAVINGS BANK
description: The Ambase Corporation plans to sell 80 percent of its troubled Carteret Savings Bank, the largest savings and loan association in New Jersey, for $200 million to a group of investors that includes the Carlyle Group and Colony Capital Inc. Carteret is burdened by a high level of nonperforming loans. The letter of intent signed by Carlyle and Colony represents Ambase's third attempt to find a rescuer for the unit, which also has branches in Florida.

title: Bills Against Car Thefts Gain in Trenton
description: The State Senate unanimously approved a five-bill package today to treat automobile theft and the ramming of police cars as serious crimes rather than juvenile pranks.

title: Taubman Is Trying Again On Initial Public Offering
description: A. Alfred Taubman's glittering shopping mall empire has taken its second shot at the public markets.

title: Saying What You Mean
description: MOST word-processing programs these days come with spelling checkers, which compare the words you have written with a dictionary-like list. But unlike a real dictionary, most of them do not tell you what the word means, so it is possible to spell the wrong word correctly.

description: Ballet Chicago is a company that not only moves with verve and precision, but also communicates its deep love of dancing to the audience. It was those qualities -- speed, clarity and brio -- that made the troupe's performance on Sunday afternoon at Brooklyn College so appealing, and so special.

description: Ross Perot's political commercials continue to be more popular than some regular prime-time entertainment shows.

CHRYSLER IS SAID TO CONSIDER SELLING LAMBORGHINI
description: The Chrysler Corporation is considering offers for the Italian auto maker Lamborghini S.p.A., which it bought in 1987 for about $25 million, according to Ward's Automotive Reports. This week's issue of the newsletter reports that the company's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, said Chrysler was weighing offers from two Italian syndicates and an American manufacturer.

title: McDonald's Agency Shed in Washington
description: DDB Needham Washington in McLean, Va., and the McDonald's Washington Regional Advertising Association have agreed to sever their 20-year relationship, they said in a joint statement released yesterday, after reports of their split appeared this week in Advertising Age and Adweek.

description: APPLE COMPUTER introduced several new PowerBook portable Macintoshes yesterday, bolstering its most popular line with more power, better displays and the ability to connect directly to a wide variety of desktop monitors.

title: Russell Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 4
McGraw-Hill Net Rises 11%
description: McGraw-Hill Inc. said yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose 11 percent on the strength of its educational and professional publishing operations as well as its financial services division.

title: HCA-Hospital Corp. of America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included after-tax charge of $ 333 million to restructure its psychiatric unit. The company said that if the restructuring charge had not occurred, it would have reported net income of $ 64,635,000, or 36 cents a share.c-Net income and share earnings are not applicable; the company went public March 4, 1992.

title: Legg Mason Profits Up 49%
description: Legg Mason Inc. said today that its fiscal second-quarter net income increased 49 percent, led by revenue gains in the corporate finance, public finance and investment advisory units.

title: Credit Markets; Bonds Drop on Fears of Clinton's Economic Plan
description: The bond market fell sharply yesterday, as investors and dealers were said to be positioning themselves for the likelihood that Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas would win the Presidential election and would try to stimulate the economy with increases in Government spending.

title: New York Finds Typical Family Being Redefined
description: The traditional American family has declined so far in New York City that married couples living with their own children now constitute only one in six households.

title: COMPAQ CUTS PRICES OF NOTEBOOK PC'S BY UP TO 32.2%
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation announced yesterday that it had cut prices of its notebook computers by as much as 32.2 percent. The price reductions are the first for the company's color portables. The company also lowered the suggested list prices on some of its desktop computers by as much as 11 percent.

title: Mildred M. Gilbert; Magazine Editor, 91
description: Mildred Morton Gilbert, a former executive editor of Vogue magazine, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91 years old.

title: Radio Scanner Owners Aren't Ham Operators
description: To the Editor:

title: Shawmut National Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $ 3 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 15.2 million, or 18 cents a share, in the 9 months, from tax-loss carryforwards.c-Net lossShawmut National said that its latest third quarter net income included securities gains of $ 11.2 million. In the year-ago quarter, the bank had securities gains of $ 15.2 million and no extraordinary credits.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In London, Earl Spencer, the father of the Princess of Wales, left an estate valued at more than $145 million. But under the terms of the will, made public yesterday, the Princess is to receive only a few mementos and the proceeds from a trust. The Earl died of a heart attack on March 29.

title: Van Dorn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes expenses of $ 1,714,000 related to the company's Crown Cork & Seal proposal, certain shareholders' lawsuits, severance costs and accrued expenses connected to the cessation of operations of a joint venture. The period also included income of $ 1,725,051, or 21 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Closing the Loop on Iran-Contra
description: George Bush's assertions about the Iran-contra scandal have seemed less and less plausible. The voluminous record of several investigative panels and the testimony of Reagan Administration officials simply contradict his denials that he knew nothing about the arms-for-hostages trade with Iran.

title: Ashland Coal reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest figures included the results of Dal-Tex Coal Corp., acquired in April 1992.

title: Transcript of 3d TV Debate Between Bush, Clinton and Perot
description: Following is a transcript of the Presidential debate at Michigan State University in East Lansing last night between President Bush, Gov. Bill Clinton and Ross Perot, as recorded by The New York Times: Credibility and Believability

title: Owens-Illinois Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains of $ 4 million, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 45.6 million, or 38 cents a share, in the 9 months, both from tax-loss carryforwards, and charges of $ 38.9 million, and $ 47.8 million, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the early extinguishment of debt. The 9 months also included a one-time gain of $ 17.8 million from the sale of the company's Japanese table glassware associate.c-Net loss and included gains of $ 900,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 3 million, or 8 cents a share, in the 9 months, both from the earnings of the company's discontinued health care segment, and a charge of $ 160 million, which is the estimated provision for the loss on the disposal of the health care segment, in the both periods. The 9 months also included an $ 11 million gain as a result of an insurance settlement.Owens-Illinois said that its operations for 1991 have been restated to reflect the health care segment, which was sold in October 1991, as a discontinued operation.

title: MANDELA'S GROUP ABUSED DISSIDENTS
description: In a new effort to show a willingness to come to grips with its past, the African National Congress admitted today that it tortured dissident members during its years in exile and said some of those responsible for human rights violations still held posts in the organization.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: In Dispute; Candidates Recount History in Their Own Way
description: In the 90 minutes of their final debate last night, the three major Presidential candidates offered voters opinions, facts, figures and history -- much of it contradictory -- on issues from civil rights to the war with Iraq.

title: BELL LABORATORIES HIRES 27 RUSSIAN RESEARCH SCIENTISTS
description: A.T.& T. Bell Laboratories, in its second such venture, said yesterday that it had hired 27 more Russian scientists, this time from St. Petersburg. The scientists, working under a one-year contract from Bell Labs, are from the A. F. Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute. They will conduct fundamental research into semiconductor physics and semiconductor lasers. As the Russian economy collapses and government subsidies disappear from huge scientific enterprises, many Western companies, including those in the United States, have become concerned that Russian scientific work would founder for want of paychecks.

title: RABIN TRIES TO WIN HELP ON THE RIGHT
description: After 100 days in office, a time for political stock-taking, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin is not yet in command of the Government he wants and is casting around for new religious and right-wing partners.

title: Raymond James Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: Share amounts give retroactive effect to the 3-for-2 stock split paid to shareholders on Feb. 3 of this year.

title: Many Reasons Send Adults to One Place: School
description: While the debate over the study of Western Civilization rages among the dons from Columbia to Stanford, Philip Dogon remains steadfast in his teaching goals: to help even the clumsiest homeowner learn to rewire a lamp or repair a toilet.

title: Review/Television; Looking for the Traces Of the First Americans
description: "The Search for the First Americans" digs into a disagreement among archeologists over when the first humans settled in North and South America. As the narrator explains in tonight's lucid edition of "Nova," it is pretty certain that by 40,000 years ago prehistoric hunters had settled in almost every part of the world, but not in the Americas, where the earliest hard evidence of a human presence goes back only 12,000 years.

title: Ekco Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Reflects an increase in bad debts related to the bankruptcy of a major customer that reduced net income by about $ 300,000, or 2 cents a share for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Union Electric Co.  reports earnings for 12mos Sept 30
Local Government Is Taken to Task As Florida Hurricane Cleanup Drags
description: Angered by the slow pace of Dade County's recovery from Hurricane Andrew and by mounting evidence of building code violations, Miami area residents are turning their frustration on county officials and the way their local government operates.

title: Saving U.S. Plants From Disorder
description: Runette Giles has to get organized. America's manufacturing future may depend on it.

title: TNT Freightways reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Central Jersey Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The bank is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: MORGAN STANLEY STAYING IN NEW YORK

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICAN BIOGENETIC SCIENCES INC., South Bend, Ind., appointed Kenneth H. Burk president and chief operating officer. American Biogenetic Sciences is a biopharmaceutical company. LIFETIME LEARNING SYSTEMS INC., Fairfield, Conn., a unit of Communications International, has named Donald J. Lay president. Lifetime Learning Systems produces supplementary teaching materials.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: New York New Music Ensemble Kathryn Bache Miller Theater

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: News Analysis; A Late-Round Flurry for Bush But Shape of Race Appears Unaltered
description: The last Presidential debate, the politicians and pundits said before it began, was President Bush's last best hope to shift the tone and the dynamics of the campaign. Do something different, they told Mr. Bush, or prepare to lose the Presidency on Nov. 3.

title: Kelly Says He'll Stress Recruiting More Blacks
description: In the first working hour of his first full day as Police Commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly visited a black-owned radio station yesterday to stress recruiting of black officers.

title: Glitches and Big Sales As New Phone System Has Broadway Debut
description: Telephone saboteurs. Busy signals. Predatory scalpers. These are the decidedly low-tech, old-fashioned problems that beset, in its first two days, the bold new high-tech era of Broadway ticket-ordering by telephone. But a lot of tickets were sold too.

title: Business Scene; Low Inflation: Is It the Culprit?
description: "MAY I suggest: 'The Great Recession'?" wrote Jeff Connor, commissioner of the New Jersey Banking Department, in response to a recent Business Scene column that reported on the search for a label that adequately describes the economic slowdown. The standard labels -- stagnation and recession -- fail to capture the hardship that many Americans say they are suffering. "Silent depression," "depressed recession," and "cycle of cycles" were among the other names suggested by readers.

title: Lawsuit From Minors Seeks to Derail Marlin Expansion Draft
description: The owners of a minor league baseball team in Florida sued the Florida Marlins in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday, seeking to block the Marlins from participating in the Nov. 17 expansion draft and from using their name and logo. The National League and its president, Bill White, also were named in the suit.

title: Armenian Chorus Cancels
description: The Yerevan Women's Chorus of Armenia, which was to perform on Friday at 8 P.M. at Symphony Space, has canceled its concert because of visa problems. Ticket holders desiring refunds should call the Symphony Space box office at (212) 864-5400.

title: Union Planters Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Union Planters said that its latest third-quarter net earnings reflected pretax securities gains of $ 9.4 million for the sale of about $ 213 million of investment securities, a pretax increase in litigation reserves of $ 3 million.The period also reflected a $ 1.3 million pretax provision for losses on owned and leased facilities as a result of the consolidation of the executive commercial lending and trust functions of Union Planters National Bank from three facilities into a new headquarters building.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Media Business page yesterday with an article about Callaway Editions Inc., which is producing the Madonna book "Sex," reversed the identifications. Charles Melcher, the publisher, was on the left, and Nicholas Callaway was on the right.

title: British Prime Minister Retreats on Mine Closings
description: Facing mass public protests and a mutiny among among members of his own Conservative Party in Parliament, Prime Minister John Major reversed ground today and sharply reduced the number of coal mines and miners' jobs scheduled for elimination by the Government.

title: High Marks Given To Metro-North
description: Most commuters in central Westchester County are now happy with the service on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, according to a survey conducted by a Westchester Assemblyman who has long been a critic of the railroad.

title: American Cyanamid reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Florida Pressuring U.S. Over Nuclear Waste
description: Florida's utilities regulators have accused Washington of "squandering" $3 billion of electricity customers' money in a fruitless search for a place to put nuclear waste.

title: Promus Companies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included loss of $ 3,446,000 on extinguishment of debt, and a gain of $ 2,699,000 on forgiveness of joint venture debt.

title: Dan-Air Plan Said to Fail
description: British Airways has dropped plans to rescue Dan-Air, owned by Davies & Newman Holdings, people close to the negotiations said yesterday. The sources said British Airways ended talks because the rescue package for the troubled Danish airline required more than it was prepared to invest. British Airways declined comment. Dan-Air was unavailable for immediate comment.

title: Odor Forces Evacuation
description: The 840 pupils at Oliver Street Elementary School were removed shortly before noon today when a bitter odor filled parts of the building, making breathing difficult and causing eyes to water, the police said. Fire and medical units from Jersey City, Elizabeth and Irvington joined the Newark Fire Department at the school in the Ironbound section. Most of the affected pupils, teachers and staff members were treated in the playground. About 12 people, including 3 teachers and 3 firefighters, were treated at nearby hospitals and released.

title: COMPANY NEWS: Teller in a Telephone; Bank to Help Customers Keep Fingers on Dollars
description: In the latest push for banking by phone, a large bank and a leading maker of telecommunications equipment are testing a new telephone that makes it easier to pay bills, transfer funds and inquire about balances. The telephone's console has a small screen that is similar to the screen of an automatic teller machine and provides voice "prompts" from a speaker phone.

title: Fort Howard reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 10,587,000 from adjustment for adoptions of SFAS 106.c-Included an extraordinary loss on debt repurchases of $ 4,869,000 and $ 1,308,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

description: b-Included a gain from accounting change of $ 1,077,000, or 73 cents a share.c-Net loss

title: National Convenience Stores Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 27% Increase In Rates Sought By Blue Cross
description: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the largest health insurance company in New York State, said yesterday that it had applied for a 27.8 percent rate increase for 1.3 million of its small-group and individual customers in the New York City, Hudson Valley and Albany areas.

title: The Chess Column
description: During the exhibition match between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky, the Tuesday chess column by Robert Byrne will not appear. The column will resume after the match.

title: Singling Out Blacks Where Few Are to Be Found; Amid Hills of Rural New York, Students From Inner City Find Not-So-Hearty Welcome
description: Derrick Forbes's first day at school was like a page torn from a journal of the old South.

title: NEC TECHNOLOGIES TO BEGIN PC SALES BY TELEPHONE
description: NEC Technologies Inc. is joining a growing list of personal computer makers that sell their wares directly to customers over the telephone. The Boxborough, Mass.-based company is a unit of the NEC Corporation of Japan. The NEC Select Solutions product line, which includes a personal computer, monitor, software and mouse in a single package, will be offered to customers calling an NEC sales center via a toll-free "800" line. NEC will also begin an advertising and direct-mail campaign to sell the personal computers through a catalogue, a concept pioneered by fast-growing competitors like Dell Computer, Zeos International and Gateway 2000.

title: Circus Plays a Role in Preserving Species
description: To the Editor:

title: Challenges Mount as School Counselors' Numbers Dwindle
description: The 17-year-old boy with the wispy mustache and the baseball cap turned backward was fuming. At first, he demanded to be transferred to a new school for safety reasons. He complained of grudge matches among Dominicans, Puerto Ricans and black students. He recounted a failed attempt to steal his $300 jacket in a school bathroom.

title: Intel Names New Chip
description: Ending months of speculation and rumor, the Intel Corporation today named its new microprocessor the Pentium processor. Pentium, a trademarked name, breaks the Intel tradition of labeling its chips with the suffix "86" as in 286, 386 and 486. Intel said it departed from its usual practice, which would have labeled this chip 586, because it had been unable to trademark the numerical system. Companies like Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and the Cyrix Corporation, which have offered clones of Intel processors using the 386 and 486 labels, would be blocked from calling their products Pentium.

title: Georgia Gulf Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Georgia Gulf said that ''continuing market conditions and lost production resulting from Hurricane Andrew had a significant impact on third quarter results.'' The company estimated that the hurricane cost $ 4 million to $ 5 million pre-tax in the third quarter.

title: Dominion Resources reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: The company said earnings were reduced by a $ 24 million refund required after the Virginia Supreme Court overturned an accounting adjustment in Virginia Power's 1990 rate case. This amounted to 11 cents a share.

title: Behind the Filming of 'The Honeymoon Killers'
description: It was a love story with a difference. She was a 200-pound nurse who only wanted to please her man. He was a smooth-talking Spaniard who preyed on lonely women and relieved them of their cash. Theirs was a passion destined for the electric chair, and for a chilling film, "The Honeymoon Killers," that the director Francois Truffaut once called "my favorite American film."

title: No Headline
description: "This always seemed like a recession-proof industry. But this time it really has affected us. You learn a lot in a year like this when people don't have money." -- FRANK L. TOBE, who sells voter lists and other services to political candidates. [ A1:5. ]

title: Once More Unto the Brink: Cuban Crisis Relived
description: Thirty years after the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, American intelligence analysts from that era gathered today to debate details of the drama that brought the world to the brink of nuclear war.

title: On My Mind; No Hiding Place
description: Now we have to hurry up and decide for ourselves the one critical question about a candidate's fitness to hold the Presidency that the debates failed to answer.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Panel Questions C.I.A. on Iraqi Arms
description: As part of its investigation of a politically sensitive bank-fraud case involving Iraq, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence has asked the Central Intelligence Agency whether American agencies set up clandestine front companies that may have helped Iraq's arms buildup, American officials have said.

title: Guzman Adds to Jays' New Confidence
description: Were it not for one unlikely swing from an unlikely hero named Ed Sprague on Sunday night, the Toronto Blue Jays would be staring at a frightening 2-0 deficit to the Atlanta Braves in the World Series. Instead, Sprague's homer has seemingly relaxed the Jays because the series is tied, it has shifted to the Skydome for three games and Juan Guzman seems ready to stare down the Braves.

title: Communications Satellite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a net restructuring charge of $ 23,400,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.c-Net incomed-After an extrarodinary charge from change in accounting method of $ 26,600,000.The company said the charge taken in the latest third quarter includes $ 17.7 million, pretax, for early retirement and reduction in force costs; $ 16.8 million, pretax, for equipment and property; and $ 4.5 million, pretax, for other items including corporate relocation to Bethesda, Md.

title: An Asian Voice for Democracy
description: Few people doubt that foreign broadcasts contributed powerfully to the democratic ferment in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. Why shouldn't American radio programs do the same in the still-Communist countries of Asia and for the unfree Burmese?

title: Deluxe Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
So, Canada, Is There Unlikely Hero for Game 3?
description: At times, the baseball lords are absolutely prescient. How else can you explain the fact that the lead article in the 1992 World Series guide is entitled "Surprise, Surprise, Surprise," promoting a Fall Classic that has already had an abundance of just that ingredient?

title: Business at the Tracks Is Beating the Odds
description: New York racing closed its 42-day autumn meeting at Belmont Park yesterday with no further erosion of attendance or betting, and officials were optimistic that the full year might show the first gain in attendance in 10 years.

title: NationsBank Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Classical Music in Review
description: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center Alice Tully Hall

title: Profit Off 17% At Dole Food
description: The Dole Food Company said today that its third-quarter earnings had fallen 17 percent, hurt by lower profit margins from table grape prices and poor results in banana operations in some markets.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: BANC ONE CORP., Columbus, Ohio, has completed the purchase of most of the deposits and offices of Diamond Savings and Loan Co., Findlay, Ohio. BURNS AEROSPACE CORP., Winston-Salem, N.C., and British Airways P.L.C. have signed a long-term agreement for the design and manufacture of aircraft seating.

title: U.S.-VIETNAM TALKS MOVE TIES CLOSER
description: Vietnam and the United States have moved closer to establishing diplomatic relations after two days of talks in Hanoi between a high-level Bush Administration delegation and Vietnamese leaders, the State Department said today.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Debate; BUSH PUSHES HARD IN 3D DEBATE BUT FOES PUT HIM ON DEFENSIVE
description: The last of the three Presidential debates ended last night with President Bush still on the defensive about his first-term record and laboring to revive his campaign by warning that Gov. Bill Clinton lacked the leadership, the record and the character to be President.

title: Blockbuster Agrees to Buy Music Store Chain
description: The Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation is taking up music.

title: Patterns
description: The Point Is Lightness

title: City Holding Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Time Warner Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes noncash amortization charges of about $ 400 million associated with the 1989 acquisition of Warner Communications.c-Net loss and included a $ 60 million one-time charge for the restructuring of the company's publishing division in the quarter and 9 months; the 9 months also included noncash amortization charges of about $ 400 million associated with the 1989 acquisition of Warner Communications.There were no share earnings in the latest periods after payment of preferred dividends.Per share figures have been restated to reflect the 4-for-1 common stock split that occurred in early September.

title: The Game 2 Slip, Blowing in the Wind
description: Ah, well, baseball was bound to cause an international incident sooner or later.

title: FEDERATED APPROVES RESTRICTED-SHARE TRADING
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that its board had agreed to allow creditors holding the company's restricted stock to trade 11 million shares on Nov. 17. The stock constitutes nearly 20 percent of the 56 million restricted shares held by some of the company's former creditors. In return for the board's decision, the group of shareholders agreed to delay a request for a secondary stock offering -- a right the creditors held as part of the reorganization that allowed Federated to emerge from bankruptcy on Feb. 5.

title: Chicago Plans Police Sweep Of Troubled Housing Area
description: Criticized as too slow in responding to the slaying of a 7-year-old boy by a sniper at a public housing development here last week, Mayor Richard M. Daley today announced a plan to sweep the projects of gangs and guns.

title: Diamond Shamrock reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FREE MARKET GAINS
description: The Communist Party announced a sweeping change in the makeup of its highest executive body today, promoting several enthusiasts of free markets to the seven-member committee that is supposed to rule China for at least the next five years.

title: Do Greens Go With Gold? Golf Thinks So
description: The possibility of including golf as a medal sport for the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta has gained the support of the game's biggest wheels, who are ready to roll out a plan in which the world's best male and female professionals would vie for gold medals at the Augusta National Golf Club.

title: Leonard Zissu, 83, Copyright Specialist
description: Leonard Zissu, an authority on copyright law and a founding member of the Copyright Society of the U.S.A., died on Sunday at the Green Manor Nursing Home in Ghent, N.Y. He was 83 years old and lived in Ancramdale, N.Y.

title: Bell Atlantic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from early extinguishment of debt of $ 6,300,000 and $ 31,400,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-Net loss and after a charge of $ 1,554,300,000 from cumulative effect of change in accounting principle--transition effect of change in accounting for post-retirement benefits other than pensions, net of tax.Year-ago results are restated for the merger wth Metro Mobile CTS, Inc., in April 1992, which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.Revenue represented total revenues.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Surrounding Scene; Bush Wins One Contest With a Sharp, Red Tie
description: They say that George Bush is at his best when he's backed into a corner, that he's a tiger on triple match point, in the last two minutes of the fourth quarter, after the second out of the ninth inning, against the ropes in the 15th round. That is when, his advisers like to say, he gets loaded for bear.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Simhath Torah, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: High Doses of Drugs Forestall Heart Transplants
description: THREE years ago, Joyette Ranker's heart mysteriously weakened, leaving her short of breath, exhausted and desperate for help. "I went to four hospitals," she said. "All the doctors said my condition was hopeless. They left me to die."

title: Capital Cities' Net Up 15.2% Despite Loss for ABC-TV
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income had risen 15.2 percent, despite a small operating loss at the ABC television network.

title: Beverly Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary losses on the prepayment of debt in both the first and second quarters, the effect of a change in accounting principle and costs related to a secondary offering of common stock in Febrauary.c-Included non-recurring charges related to the company's initial public offering in May 1991.

title: Moons Galore
description: As many as 1,000 moons ranging in size from a half mile to six miles in diameter may populate the faint rings around each of the planets Uranus and Neptune, two scientists at the University of Colorado have reported.

title: Pacific Bank N.A. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Nurses Taste What It's Like When You're Elderly and in the Hospital
description: There they were, a roomful of nurses feeding each other crackers that crumbled on their chest, juice that dribbled down their chin, and spoons laden with orange Jell-O that tasted like grandma's punishment for sassing.

title: Howard Lipman, Art Collector And Ex-Whitney Head, 87, Dies
description: Howard W. Lipman, an art collector and a former chairman of the Whitney Museum of American Art, died on Sunday at his home in Carefree, Ariz., his son announced yesterday. He was 87 years old.

title: Review/Fashion; Amid Trends, Room For Individuality
description: Of the major designers who presented their spring and summer collections over the weekend, Claude Montana was the modernist, Christian Lacroix the most decorative and Karl Lagerfeld for Chanel the trend-setter . Valentino carried the banner for Italian design. Issey Miyake of Tokyo used modern technology to create unusual visual effects with fabrics.

title: Editorial Notebook; Albany's Secret Ways
description: State Senator Nancy Larraine Hoffman, a Democrat, has two traits her Syracuse-area constituents find endearing. The same traits exasperate many of her colleagues in the clubby Republican-run New York State Senate: She's independent and outspoken. After eight years in the Senate, she has emerged as the most vocal critic of the self-serving way the Legislature operates.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Canadiens Stop Blues Todd Ewen scored twice, including the tie-breaking goal in the third period, as the Montreal Canadiens beat the St. Louis Blues by 6-2 last night in Montreal. Ewen, acquired from St. Louis in 1989, got two goals in a game for the first time in his career. He scored once in the opening period and then added the game-winner on a breakaway to start Montreal's four-goal burst. Ed Ronan, Brian Bellows, Guy Carbonneau and Denis Savard also scored for Montreal, which won its second straight game. Nelson Emerson and Brendan Shanahan scored for St. Louis, which tied the game at 2-2 after two periods. Montreal, coming off an 8-1 defeat of Minnesota on Saturday, outshot the Blues, 33-27. Ronan got his first National Hockey League goal 6 minutes 9 seconds into the game when he took advantage of a mixup at the St. Louis blue line to go in alone and beat goalie Curtis Joseph on the backhand. The St. Louis defense was caught standing around when Mathieu Schneider set up Ewen alone at the side of the net for an easy tap-in almost three minutes later to make it 2-0. (AP) BASKETBALL Playing for a Cause The victims of Hurricane Andrew will have $500,000 more to help them rebuild their lives, thanks to the Chicago Bulls and the Miami Heat. The Bulls beat the Heat, 111-94, last night in an exhibition game to raise money for We Will Rebuild, a hurricane-relief organization. All revenues from the game -- ticket receipts, concessions, parking fees -- along with donations called in by fans watching the nationally televised game on TNT, will go to hurricane relief. The idea for the game came from the Bulls' Michael Jordan, who suggested it to Billy Cunningham, the former N.B.A. star who is a partner in the Heat's ownership. Seated in the approximately 740 courtside seats in the Miami Arena were children who were left homeless or whose families suffered great damage because of the hurricane. (AP)

title: French Try To Delay Trade Deal
description: France sought to damp hopes today of an early breakthrough in long-stalled world trade liberalization talks, arguing that the Bush Administration was in no position to close a deal before the Presidential election on Nov. 3.

title: As Simple as Child's Play? New Complexity Is Found
description: IF play among nonhuman mammals has evolved for a vivid tapestry of reasons, from stimulating circuits in the brain to helping an animal learn to tame its hostile impulses, in children play reaches the pinnacle of complexity.

title: At Edge of Campaign, Jackson Labors On for Democratic Victory

If he searched the length of the United States, he probably could not find a place more removed from the hot lights of national politics than this small town on the Canadian border.

title: Review/Rock; Mixing Love, Freud and Forbidden Planets
description: At Maxwell's in Hoboken, N.J., on Thursday night, many of the Chills' songs came with soft-spoken introductions from the lead singer, Martin Phillipps. "This is an apology to women for all the things we blokes do to you," he said before "Male Monster From the Id," from the Chills' fourth and latest album, "Soft Bomb" (Slash/Reprise). More so than with most garage rockers, Mr. Phillipps's songs benefit from an introduction: he constructs them with a scrupulous, obsessive attention to language detail that can be lost amid the rush of the live setting. "Male Monster From the Id" has references to Freudian psychology, Superman and Mr. Hyde, cavemen and forbidden planets. It's not a typical love song.

title: 19, Count 'Em, 19 Candidates Run for Mayor in Jersey City
description: Jersey City's voters will elect their fourth mayor in a year next month. To do so they will have to choose among 19 candidates, including two feuding brothers.

description: A transit police officer shot and killed a teen-ager last night in subway car in the Bronx after the youth pulled a gun on the officer, a spokesman for the transit police said.

title: Better Earnings at Citicorp and Chemical
description: Profits at Citicorp and the Chemical Banking Corporation improved considerably in the third quarter compared with a year ago while net income at Wells Fargo & Company dropped 72 percent. But the performance of the three was overshadowed by several other large banks across the country, which had earnings that were at or near record levels.

title: Accounts
description: * Colours, Hackensack, N.J., a chain of cosmetics boutiques, to Pointblank Advertising, New York, as its first agency. Billings were not disclosed. * Bell Atlantic Metro Mobile, Wallingford, Conn., to Mason & Madison, New Haven, for marketing communications; the agency already handles assignments like public relations for the cellular telephone company. Mason & Madison was also named to handle advertising for the Davison Chemical division of W. R. Grace & Co., Baltimore. Combined billings for both accounts will be $3 million.

title: Judge to Weigh Damage in Reynolds Case
description: A judge in Columbus, Ohio, will decide over the next few weeks whether the quarter-miler BUTCH REYNOLDS is entitled to as much as $27.3 million from the ruling body of international track and field. United States District Judge JOSEPH KINNEARY heard arguments yesterday from attorneys in Reynolds's lawsuit against the International Amateur Athletic Federation.

title: U S West Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Paccar Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income of $ 15.4 million, or 46 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting method for income taxes.The company is listed on the Nasdaq National Market System.

title: Agreement Reached on Appointment of Bronx Principals
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez and a Bronx school district have reached an out-of-court settlement on the appointment of six principals whose assignment Mr. Fernandez had sought to block amid accusations of corruption, political cronyism and anti-Semitism in the district board's selection process.

title: Books of The Times; Madonna Writes; Academics Explore Her Erotic Semiotics
description: Sex By Madonna Photographs by Steven Meisel. Unpaginated. Warner Books. $49.95.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats; CLINTON IS LEERY OF PREMATURE JOY
description: As they huffed about the asphalt of Midway Airport, tossing a football in one of the quadrennial rites of autumn, Gov. Bill Clinton and Senator Al Gore could not stop grinning, and neither could their aides.

title: In Long Run, Family Leave Will Be a Bargain; Broad Bills Vetoed
description: To the Editor:

title: Santa Fe Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pretax charges of $ 325 million for costs associated with a recently ratified rail crew consist agreement, rail operations centralization and increased environmental accruals at Santa Fe Railway and Santa Fe Pacific Pipeline Partners L.P.c-Net income

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a study of fruit flies, showing that life expectancy may not always decrease as organisms get older, misstated the affiliation of Dr. James W. Curts inger. He is at the University of Minnesota, not the University of Wisconsin.

title: U.S. GIVEN PHOTOS BY HANOI OF 5,000
description: The Pentagon has obtained up to 5,000 photographs of dead Americans from Vietnam that may help clear up the fate of some missing servicemen, American officials and researchers said today.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Christina Kiss Pianist Weill Recital Hall

title: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
With Cash Tight, Abrams Forgoes Pressing Flesh for Raising Money
description: Vastly out-financed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato -- and thus eclipsed in the battle of television commercials -- Attorney General Robert Abrams is in the thick of the most elaborate, and desperate, fund-raising drive of his quarter-century in politics.

title: American Brands reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports of The Times; Series Prize Should Be 1996 Games
description: THESE are not the Blue Jays we used to know. They do not give up. They do not go away. Two more victories like this and they could even exorcise some of the old conspiracy theories about their giant neighbor to the south.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY BUYS CENTRAL STATES INDEMNITY
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire an 82 percent interest in Central States Indemnity from the Central States Health and Life Company of Omaha and other owners in a deal worth about $82 million. Central States Indemnity's primary product line is credit-card credit insurance distributed through card issuers nationwide. Its revenues this year are expected to exceed $96 million, the company said, and its net earnings from operations should be about $10 million.

title: Mighty Menopause
description: "Be useful as well as ornamental" was one of my father's favorite sayings when I was growing up. And it looks as if I wasn't the only girl who heard it.

title: York International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 18,348,000.

title: Study Finds Most Parents Know About Daughters' Abortion Plans
description: A new nationwide study of 1,500 teen-age girls who had abortions last year found that 61 percent of the parents knew about the abortions in advance even without any law requiring parental notification or consent.

title: F.B.I. Is Seeking Missing Antiquities
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating the disappearance of three Egyptian antiquities that were shipped on Oct. 1 to the Merrin Gallery in Manhattan from the Cleveland Museum of Art, but never arrived.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: AFFLICTED WITH A SCIENTIFIC ENIGMA

title: Reebok International Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Reebok International said that per share comparisons benefited from the April 8, 1991 repurchase of 24,460,902 shares.

title: Mob and Politics Intersect, Fueling Cynicism in Japan
description: In 1987 Noboru Takeshita and his faction in the ruling party wielded immense influence in Japan -- more, some said, than the Government. But he was powerless to remove the last obstacle to his becoming Prime Minister: the loud, mocking attacks from a rightist group's sound trucks.

title: Iran-Contra Document Says Bush Favored Secrecy in Hostage Affair
description: A White House document, little-noticed before, shows that in November 1986 George Bush endorsed a Reagan Administration plan to conceal the specifics of the Iran initiative as details of the secret arms-for-hostage arrangement began spilling into public view.

title: Melville Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
For Anderson, Defense 101
description: Neither a crowd of 28,602 at his college stomping ground nor the appearance of the Chicago Bulls could move Derrick Coleman off the New Jersey Nets' bench tonight. His sprained right ankle still hurt.

title: Women Advance in Politics By Evolution, Not Revolution
description: In this acidic political season in which Anita Hill has become a shorthand for outrage and the "Year of the Woman" is a familiar refrain, it is easy to believe that revolution is at hand.

title: Belgrade Signs 2d Pact With Croatia
description: The Presidents of Croatia and the truncated Yugoslavia signed another agreement today on a series of steps to ease tension and create confidence among hostile ethnic communities.

title: Shiite Gunman Now Speaker of Lebanese House
description: The Lebanese Parliament, given a new mandate in the first national elections in two decades, held its opening session here today and chose Nabih Berri, a former commander of the country's largest Muslim militia and an ally of Syria, to be its Speaker for the next four years.

title: Avon Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 64.4 million for restructuring.c-Net lossd-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 75,000,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Eating Well
description: THE food police have been working overtime. In recent months it's been announced that too much iron in the blood might cause heart disease, milk might trigger diabetes and allergies and margarine can raise blood cholesterol levels.

title: Maxxam Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
C.D. Yields Are Mixed For Week
description: Yields offered on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit turned mixed in the week that ends today, giving depositors some respite from the steady drop in bank rates since July, when the Federal Reserve cut the discount rate and most large banks subsequently cut their prime lending rates.

title: In Long Run, Family Leave Will Be a Bargain; Staying Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Lester S. Lipsitch; Retired Hospital Chief, 80
description: Dr. Lester S. Lipsitch, a former chief of staff of the American Hospital of Paris, died Oct. 17 at his home in Longboat Key, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: IRAQ CASE REVEALS 3-WAY TUG-OF-WAR
description: When Representative Henry B. Gonzalez stood on the House floor last month and began reading from Central Intelligence Agency reports about Italy's role in a multibillion-dollar bank fraud, the Federal prosecutors who had spent three years investigating the case were stunned.

title: Clinton Pledge vs. Clinton Plan
description: I will not raise taxes on the middle class to pay for my programs.

title: Bonn Signals It May Cut Key Rates
description: The Bundesbank signaled today that it was cautiously guiding Germany's money-market rates lower, raising hopes in the world's financial markets that the German central bank might cut its key interest rates before the end of the year.

title: Phelps Dodge reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 36.4 million, or 52 cents a share, from the sale to Sumitomo Corp. of a 20 percent interest in the Phelps Dodge La Candelaria copper project in northern Chile.All per-share figures have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split in June.

title: Review/Opera; Dimitrova in Lead Of First 'Tosca' Of the Met Season
description: Beneath the gaudy melodrama of "Tosca" lies Puccini's most concise and close-knit score. The lavish melodies given to the protagonists may linger longest in the ear, but the spare motifs and modulations associated with Scarpia are at the core of the opera's power. This quality was furthest from Franco Zeffirelli's mind when he designed his plush and pompous "Tosca" for the Met in 1985; this season's revival cuts down on some of the distracting excess, but still fights the logic of Puccini's music.

title: It Becomes a Lost Night For Braves' Manager
description: Jeff Blauser thought he had checked his swing, but the first-base umpire, Dan Morrison, waved, signaling a strikeout. In the Braves' dugout, Bobby Cox picked up a batting helmet and bounced it off the floor, thinking it would remain in the dugout. But when it ricocheted onto the artificial turf, plate umpire Joe West ejected the Braves' manager.

title: Open Skies, Friendlier Skies
description: British Airways and USAir. Lufthansa and Continental. KLM and Northwest. Since July, European airlines have been lining up to combine operations with weak U.S. carriers. If the "mergers" go through, which is far from certain, Americans can expect lower fares and better service.

title: Cairo Journal; After the Earthquake, a Rumbling of Discontent
description: Dressed in an expensive white blouse and a black skirt, a Government official stood on a street here handing out out money and documents to a crowd of disheveled earthquake victims.

title: Ahmanson (H.F.) & Co. (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Theater -- The Destiny of Me; Larry Kramer Tells His Own Anguished Story
description: "What do you do when you're dying from a disease you need not be dying from?" cries out Ned Weeks, the autobiographical hero of Larry Kramer's new play, "The Destiny of Me." If you are Larry Kramer, a founder of the Gay Men's Health Crisis and Act Up as well as the author of "The Normal Heart," you keep crying out: in the streets, on "Nightline" or, at this moment, from the stage of the Lucille Lortel Theater, where the Circle Repertory Company is giving his blistering confessional drama its premiere. As the AIDS epidemic courses into its second decade, Mr. Kramer, weakened by the effects of H.I.V. but still slugging, won't stop shouting at those in authority who he feels impede the search for a cure.

title: Jays Squeeze Out of Tight Spot Into a 2-1 Lead
description: The combination of playing indoors and in the first World Series game ever played in Canada was too great an obstacle for the Atlanta Braves to overcome tonight.

title: Market Place; Another Look At TV Shopping
description: PERCEIVED as a hot property in the mid-1980's, Home Shopping Network has recently been little more than a favorite target of the joke meisters who work on Wall Street's equity trading desks.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Persichetti Remembered Bruno Walter Auditorium

title: N.F.L. Inches Ever Closer to New Free-Agency Plan
description: National Football League owners today listened to proposals on a new free-agency system and discussed the idea of a more intense bargaining effort to resolve their differences with players. They targeted Nov. 12 as a date for choosing a course of action that would help solve their labor woes.

title: But the Fighter Still Remains in Belmont; After 59 Years of Taking It on the Chin, Bobby Halpern Can Still Throw a Punch
description: Bobby Halpern pummeled the heavy bag. He can still punch. With each sweaty blow, his muscles tensed and ripples rose beneath the pink scars that document a distinctly unusual life: This body, sagging only slightly under the weight of his 59 years, has withstood bullets, knives, prison beatings and more opponents than he can count.

title: No Headline
description: "You got a sense of priorities. You got a sense of their personal engagement in different issues. They're not all engaged in the same issues. You got a sense of the depth of their understanding of the issues. And you got a general sense of direction." -- CHARLES O. JONES of the University of Wisconsin, assessing the Presidential debates. [ A19:5. ]

title: How to Keep Business in New York
description: Mayor David Dinkins deserves credit for encouraging the Morgan Stanley Group, one of the nation's leading financial services firms, to keep its corporate headquarters in New York City for at least the next decade. Had Morgan Stanley moved to a parcel it had optioned in Stamford, Conn., it might have led other large financial firms to consider leaving -- and thus jeopardized the city's status as the world's financial services center.

title: Gruber Not So Sure He Has Won Over the Fans
description: Kelly Gruber has heard boos at the Skydome for so long that it is almost comical. He hears it when he bats, he hears it when he flubs a grounder and he hears it during batting practice. The polite Blue Jay fans do not hammer many players, but Gruber is their target for abuse.

title: Review/Television; 2 Roads to the Presidential Campaign
description: Frontline The Choice '92 PBS, tonight at 9 (Channel 13 in New York)

title: Review/Film; Russia on Analyst's Couch
description: "Interpretation of Dreams" was shown as part of the 1991 New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 30, 1991. The film opens today at Film Forum 1, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: Penn Central reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from an accounting adjustment of $ 130.3 million, or $ 2.75 a share, from the company's adoption during the second quarter of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 109, or Accounting for Income Taxes, effective Jan. 1 of this year. The period also included a loss of $ 2 million from discontinued operations, which was from the July 1 spinoff to shareholders of a company called General Cable Corp.c-Included income of $ 100,000 in the quarter and a loss of $ 1.6 million in the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Italy's Goal Is to Play in Giants Stadium
description: With just a few timely goals, the Italian national soccer team could play five matches at Giants Stadium in front of huge, adoptive crowds during the 1994 World Cup tournament.

title: Another Met Undergoes Surgery
description: Outfielder PAT HOWELL has undergone arthroscopic surgery on his right knee, bringing to 12 the number of Mets who have been operated on this year.

title: BORG-WARNER MOVES TO GO PUBLIC AGAIN
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation, which was taken private in a 1987 leveraged buyout backed by Merrill Lynch & Company, sought the approval yesterday of the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 3.3 million common shares publicly. The shares would be priced at $17 to $19 each, with proceeds used to repay part of the company's debt.

title: Review/Fashion; Bare Midriffs And a Singular Opulence
description: Couture and ready-to-wear collections usually operate on separate tracks, with different showing times, customers and attitudes. But there are signs that the tracks are converging.

title: With CashTight, Abrams Forgoes Pressing Flesh for Raising Money
description: Vastly out-financed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato -- and thus eclipsed in the battle of television commercials -- Attorney General Robert Abrams is in the thick of the most elaborate, and desperate, fund-raising drive of his quarter-century in politics.

title: Bitter Greens Come in From the Cold
description: PASTA with bitter greens is a dish making its way into mainstream American cooking. The movement probably began with broccoli rape, the Italian bitter green that has become popular in the last five years. Now, Americans have become more adventuresome, willing to try any number of greens that, until recently, only those brought up on them would eat. Arugula, Swiss chard and mustard greens are among them.

title: Welcome to Prague, Boom Town
description: In February 1990, just three months after the fall of Communism, Grady Lloyd, arrived here to lead a program that has brought hundreds of eager young American and Canadian volunteers to Czechoslovakia to teach English.

title: Chrysler's Surprising Profits
